title: swabs watch dirty toilet
story: The new research also showed only one in four Brits have never cleaned their watches.Tic Watches swabbed  dferent kinds of watches to test for aerobic bacteria, yeast and mould to find out how many germs really latch on.The stomach-churning results showed each watch had a concerning amount of bacteria, yeast and mould - scoring an average of three times dirtier than a toilet seat.However, the biggest offender was a fitness watch.The Fitbit tested a shocking eight times dirtier than a toilet set and flush handle - the plastic and leather watches are more foul than the metal ones.The least dirty watch was a mans leather-strap watch - scoring just . times dirtier than a toilet seat.The UK watch brand also found that  per cent of Brits admitted they never cleaned their watch, while one in five cleaned their watches less than every six months.Daniel Richmond, Managing Director of Tic Watches, said of the research: Whether you wear a watch every day, or just during working hours, one thing is for certain, we dont clean them as much as we wash our hands.Unfortunately, not all watches are waterproof, so avoiding any contact with water when were wearing them could be the main reason for a build-up of bacteria.. Get a bowl in soapy water. Soak the bands. Scrub away the dirt. Give it a rinse. Clean the watch head. Dry thoroughly. Reattach the componentsFor those who wear a watch every day, we recommend giving it a good clean at least once a month.If you think your watch is due a clean, take a look at our tips to see how to do it yourself or you can even take it to a specialist shop for a professional clean.Not only will this keep your watch looking as good as new, but it will keep unsafe bacteria at bay.

title: seatbelt cover save child life
story: The ingenious device slips over a seatbelt and alerts emergency services to childrens health issues or disabilities.Natalie Bell, from Victoria, Australia, came up with the le-saving cover after her daughter had a cochlear implement fitted.She said: I always wonder what would happenI was in a car accident with my daughter in the car and I was unable to let the doctors know that my daughter could not have a MRI due to having a cochlear implant.Now I dont need to worry about that with these seat belt covers.These can be made for any special needs that the medical team will need to knowyou are unable to tell them.These children might have a medical bracelet but those are quite small.So I thought this is something emergency services would notice straight away.Thousands of people have contacted Natalie asking for versions for autism and other conditions.They sell for £ each - and two are just £.One Facebook user wrote: My husband is part of Fire and Rescue and said that this is a brilliant idea.Such a valuable piece that provides a lot of information clearly so that personal involved can approach situations with knowledge and care.Another added: This is an amazing idea! As a cop I wish I could hand these out to anyone who needs them.A third wrote: This is also a great idea for adults with dementia.

title: family grave council skip
story: Flintshire Council told furious Paula Roberts that they dumped the soil box on dad Alans grave for health and safety reasons.Retired delivery driver Alan, , died last November after losing a cancer battle.Bizarre pictures show a large skip full of earth crushing the entire plot - and several ornamental vases.Paula said: We had been up to the cemetery on Fathers Day and put down fresh flowers.I took my mum up to see the grave days later and as we were walking towards it I said I cant see the balloon we attached to the grave the week before.I thought it must have blown away and my mum what the hells that  As we got closer, I could see this big skip type container on top of my dads grave.All the vases and ornaments and gts wed placed on the grave on Fathers Day were smashed up.My mum was just hysterical, I havent seen her cry that much since my dad passed away.The workmen had literally picked up the gts and flowers we had placed by the grave and thrown everything into the mud.I phoned up the council and a lady said it must have been due to health and safety reasons, I said there is no reason that should be on my dads grave.There are just no words to describe how upsetting this has been. Its just totally disrespectful and disgusting.Council spokesman Steve Jones said: Lessons will be learnt from the case and adopted to avoid a repeat occurrence.

title: woman taped puppy mouth shut utah
story: Alexis Callen, , admitted she tied Shadows snout for two days, but veterinarians believe it was shut for two weeks, causing severe disfiguration.The Black Labrador retriever-Alsatian mix is expected to make a full recovery, but she requires £,worth of reconstructive surgery so she can eat and drink normally again.She needs immediate medical care as the left side of her snout has been sliced so severely you can see the inside of the mouth even when her jaw is closed.Celestial Zoo, a Utah County cat and dog rescue, first discovered Shadows injuries when Callen posted on Facebook about looking to rehome her puppy because she couldnt afford her treatment.The group shared images of Callens post with a picture of Shadow, who appears wet, with the raw injury to her snout visible.Callen, of Murray, Utah, first blamed Shadows injuries on a neighbour, but later told authorities it was her.The teens post read: My puppy got hurt badly and I dont have the expenses to pay for her to go to the vet to get stitches, so Im here to rehome her.Shes a Lab German Shepard mix. Pm me for info,also anyone who bashes on me will be blocked from talking to me.Celestial Zoo then shared what appeared to be comments from Callens post where she blames the injury on a dog sitter, even though her name is covered in the screenshots.The comment reads: I had to make an emergency trip to see my family so i had someone in my complex watch her.When I got back her snout was tied shut and swollen, i tried to do what i could to help her but i dont have the expenses to pay for her to get stitches or healed properly.It goes on: It wasnt even a muzzle that they used, they said they did it because she wouldnt stop whining.Callen now faces a felony torture charge.Caylla Facemyer, Shadows new foster mum, told Fox : Left side [of her nose], its completely open even with her mouth closed.You can see into her mouth. Its pretty bad.Celestial Zoo is now seeking donations to help for Shadows surgery.They gave an update on Shadows condition on June  saying: The vet looked it over and cleaned it up.Gave her some antibiotics and pain meds.The left side has already separated and will need surgery.The right side may as well. It looks to be a rubber band or hair tie around her muzzle that caused it, left on for a week or two.She’ll need to be seen again in a few days and then we’ll see what we need to do for surgery.Celestial Zoo also shared news about Callens arrest later that same day.The group said: Shadow had to go back to the vet today for a cone, but even though she is not happy about her cone, she is happy to report that thanks to the quick action of the Murray Animal Control officers, an arrest has been made on felony animal abuse charges.We are thrilled at the quick action and hope that justice is found. She still has a long road and surgeries ahead of her, but she’s expected to make a full recovery.One Friday they announced Shadows surgery had been scheduled.

title: jet2 passenger hijack emergency exit
story: A terried fellow passenger told how the -year-old woman had her hands on exit door before cabin crew dragged her to the ground.Amy Varol, who sat two rows behind, said: The woman was walking down the aisle when she literally ran to the exit door.She had her hands on the handle trying to open it.Luckily there were two cabin crew there who pulled her off the door.Then the woman allegedly went for the cockpit door before a male passenger threw her to the floor.Ms Varol continued: She started assaulting the two crew members, a woman and a man.A big guy then literally threw her down to the floor and there was one person holding one arm and another person holding the other.Then a man sat on her and one person was holding her leg and someone  holding the other one.Thats when she started screaming get off me, Im going to kill everyone.The -year-old community care worker said it was chaos on the plane.She said: The whole plane started screaming as the crew tried to get her off the door.Everyone all of a sudden jumped up and panicked.Children were crying and the elderly people ran to the back of the plane to hide.Two RAF Typhoon fighters scrambled to intercept the Airbus  and escort it back to Stansted Airport as she allegedly threatened to kill passengers.Ms Varol, from Herts., said she saw one of the fighter jets outside the window flanking the plane.Our exclusive video shows the intoxicated woman being pinned to a seat by six cabin crew and passengers, then being led away by cops amid the mid-air panic.Police said a -year-old woman was arrested on suspicion of assault an endangering an aircraft after landing in Essex at .pm on Saturday.Terried passengers told The Sun Online how a woman in her s tried to rush the cockpit  minutes into the flight from Stansted to Dalaman, Turkey.Ms Varol said: This lady who was clearly intoxicated gets called to the front of the plane and she starts shouting and screaming and runs to the plane door.The cabin crew grabbed her to stop her and then she starts scratching them and hitting them.She then got pinned to the floor by cabin crew and passengers and a passenger even sat on her.Ms Varol said the woman made threats to other passengers and staff.She said: She kept getting up and running back towards the door.She had six people sitting on her. We had to fly back to Stansted for the police to get her.She kept singing songs and screaming she’s gonna kill us, I want to get off, I’m gonna f****** hit you f***** come on then.I was terried. There’s nothing you can do, you can’t escape.Stewart Brown, who was six rows behind, said a woman in her early s started to irritate passengers as soon as they took off.The -year-old mobile DJ told The Sun Online: The air stewards did their best to calm her down.She seemed absolutely fine before takeoff but then strangely very drunk or drugged as we took off.The stewards gave her several chances and did the best they could before she became abusive and then made a dash for the cockpit and had to be restrained by staff and passengers.We had to turn round and police removed her off the plane.A Jet spokesman said: “We are aware of an incident regarding an extremely disruptive passenger on a flight from Stansted to Dalaman earlier this evening.The aircraft has ed safely and we are liaising with the relevant authorities to support their investigation.We are working hard to ensure the remaining customers reach their destination as soon possible.Many people living near Stansted phoned police to report a loud noise they thought could be an explosion.One man described the noise as a huge bang which nearly blew my window out.Twitter users said their windows rattled and tellys shook as far away as Chelmsford  miles away and even Ilford in East London, about  miles from the airport.Police in Bishops Stortford, Hertfordshire, tweeted: Large number of  calls coming in about a loud explosion.We have liaised with @EssexPoliceUK who are confirming that this is a sonic boom from a passing aircraft.A sonic boom is created when supersonic aircraft accelerate through the sound barrier - which is banned over land except in emergencies.A Royal Air Force spokeswoman said: “We can confirm that RAF quick reaction alert Typhoon aircraft from RAF Coningsby scrambled to escort a commercial flight into Standard shortly after take-off due to reports of a disruptive passenger.”Essex Police said: We were made aware of a disruptive passenger on an inbound flight to Stansted this evening, Saturday, June .There is a possibility that residents nearby may have heard a loud noise, often associated with a sonic boom, as the aircraft descended into Stansted airspace.Officers attended and arrested a -year-old woman on suspicion of two assaults and endangering an aircraft.She remains in custody.The drama was said to have caused minor delays at Stansted but a spokesman said the airport resumed normal operations.Meanwhile football manager Sam Allardyce was among hundreds of passengers stuck in huge delays after an IT meltdown at Manchester Airport.

story: Tim Vessey, , almost fell off his scaffolding when the lb bird whacked him.The magpie swooped down and plucked the chicken from an open kitchen window where it had been left to defrost.Tim and his colleagues, who were working on the roof of a neighbouring house, watched in amazement as it soared away.He said: “We couldn’t believe it managed to fly off with it.“But then I got a bigger surprise a few seconds later.“There was a sudden bang on the top of my head, an almighty wallop.“The bird obviously lost its grip on the chicken just as it flew over my head.”The ex-soldier, from mansfield, Notts, added: “It’s a good job I had my work hat on or it could have knocked me out.“I could have fallen off the scaffold with a ft drop.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mps claim free tv licence oaps bbc
story: Three hundred and twenty members of parliament have claimed £. for a TV licence for their second home or constituency, according to figures.The bill which taxpayers have been forced to pay has reached £, since , according to the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority .One claimant is Jeremy Wright, the culture secretary, who was reimbursed for a licence for his London flat until , reports The Times.He has claimed another for his constituency office in Kenilworth, near Coventry, since .Mr Wright this month slammed the BBC after it announced plans to axe free licences for over-s, except for the poorest pensioners.Campaign groups said it was unfair that he and other MPs, paid at least £,, continue to enjoy the perk.George McNamara, of the charity Independent Age, said: “Pensioners will see this as extremely insulting. It seems there’s one rule for the MPs and another for them.”MPs are allowed to claim for a TV licence in their constituency office, according to Ipsa, and were eligible to claim for one for their second home until .More than , people have signed petitions calling on the government to protect free TV licences for over-s.The end of the universal free TV licence for the over-s is a breach of the  Tory election manesto but the current Government is powerless to step in because it handed over responsibility for funding the TV licence fee to the BBC in  as part of its new charter.But Matt Hancock, a former Culture Secretary, said the BBC should reverse the decision by slashing costs where in the organisation.He also said he would conduct a radical overhaul of the way the BBC is run so it is fit for the digital age.Mr Hancock said: “They should live within their means. The bigger question is what the BBC will do to fund itself in the digital age where in a decade’s time it won’t be clear what a “TV” is anymore.An unprecedented number of letters were sent in to The Sun following the BBC’s announcement that it would start means-testing for the giveaway from June  .Furious pensioners registered their backing for our campaign to reverse the BBC decision.Many branded the concept of a licence fee as “outdated” in a world of digital streaming.Others said it was immoral for BBC boss Tony Hall to penalise pensioners when he was paying sky-high salaries to presenters such as Gary Lineker and Graham Norton.Campaigners said that although the changes appear to make the system fairer it will make watching TV unaffordable for , pensioners.Elderly Brits took to the airwaves to vent their anger and disappointment at the BBC yesterday, with GMB Presenter Susanna Reid fighting back tears when an elderly woman explained how TV was her main source of entertainment and begged the Beeb to rethink its decision.The BBC’s callous decision to sting .million OAPs for £ a year — pleading poverty despite its £billion annual subsidy — should be the last straw.Hundreds of thousands  may forget to pay, or refuse. And it will be an outrageANY of society’s most vulnerable people are dragged to court and punished.If the Government will not scrap the licence fee entirely, the BBC must cut executive salaries and waste, reduce its services and relent over old folk.If it won’t, its power must be limited to cutting off services, like an energy firm does as a last resort, and only then the live TV or iPlayer the licence covers.Luckily there’s plenty more now to watch.

title: men netflix poorer quality sperm
story: It comes after they quizzed  men on their sperm quality and sleep habits at Danish fertility clinics.Those who stayed up late were less likely to meet the World Health Organisation standard for “normal” sperm.It means they had a low sperm count or poorly formed sperm, which can struggle to swim and fertilise eggs.Fellas were . times more likely to have normal spermthey nodded off before .pm than between .pm and .pm.And this rose to almost four timesmore likely when compared with those who went to bed even later.Men who slept between . and  hours a night were . times more likely to meet the standard than those who kipped for fewer than seven.But the quality of sleep, such as the number of times they woke in the night, made no dference, Aarhus University found.Evidence suggests sleep deprivation can cause the immune system to overreact and attack sperm.And going to bed late may also see couples running out of time to romp.Prof Hans Jakob Ingerslev, who worked on the study, said: “Early bedtimes and sleep durations of . to . hours were associated with higher semen quality.“The study suggests potential areas of optimisation in relation to treatment of male infertility.” Dr Raj Mathur, from Manchester University NHS Foundation Trust, commented: “The study suggests men who are trying for a baby should be going to bed early and getting a decent amount of sleep.“They should think about what is keeping them up and try to change their habits, whether it’s binge-watching Netflix or sending emails.“Going to bed earlier with their partner may also increase their opportunity for sex, improving their chances of success further.“Studies show there are numerous health benefits from going to bed early and getting a good amount of sleep.“There is a link between the body’s endocrine system, which controls hormones, and the body clock.” The findings were presented at the annual meeting of the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology in Vienna, Austria. Our title: istanbul election turkey erdogan loses
story: Ekrem Imamoglu, , said thank you to his supporters after his victory on Sunday - the second time the election took place amid weeks of political tension.Imamoglu narrowly won an earlier mayoral election on March  - but Erdogans Justice and Development Party, AKP, challenged the vote over alleged irregularities.He spent  days in office before Turkeys electoral board annulled the results after weeks of partial recounts.Last night, unofficial results showed he won a clear majority of the vote - beating former Turkish Prime Minister Binali Yildirim  per cent to  per cent.Imamoglu increased his lead from the March mayoral election by hundreds of thousands of votes - suggesting a voter backlash against Erdogans efforts to further seize power.But analysts say the president - who is grappling with an economic downturn and several international crises - could limit the mayors power or undermine Imamoglus authority in other ways.It was feared after the initial result was voided that AKP - which has governed Turkey since  - would never accept any electoral loss.Imamoglu told jubilant crowds last night: You have protected the reputation of democracy in Turkey with the whole world watching.Supporters chanted Mayor again! Mayor again! while others hung out of cars, blaring horns and waving red-and-white Turkish flags.Erdogan will be devastated after campaigning hard for Yildirim in Istanbul - where the president started his political career as mayor in .AKP also lost control of the capital city of Ankara in Turkeys March local elections.It came as the country battled high inflation and two credit rating downgrades in the past year.Istanbul - a city of more than  million - draws millions of tourists each year and is Turkeys commercial and cultural hub, accounting for  per cent of Turkeys GDP in .Erdogan has previously signalled an unwillingness to work with an opposition mayor.But Imamoglu will have to work with his party to govern Istanbul - and he promised to do so on Sunday.Addressing Erdogan in a speech, Imamoglu said: Im ready to work with you to solve Istanbuls problems.

title: theresa may private jets brexit deal
story: The PM made over  trips to member states costing half a million from when she took over as PM in July  until the most recent figures in December last year.It means the total cost for chartered flights and No.  Squadron RAF trips is even higher as she made more last ditch efforts to get her hated deal over the line this year.Figures show the jet costs alone were £, and extras including accommodation and meals added on £,.The PM would have been expected to make European Council meetings and NATO summits regardless of Brexit but the negotiations saw a huge increase in trips.Before David Cameron entered talks for his  EU referendum deal he visited Europe just ten times in  - half the  times May flew to Europe per year on average.And Cameron took just four trips to Brussels while May was in the Belgium capital roughly every six weeks.His total European travel bill to the taxpayer was just £, in  but May nearly levelled that on each journey with trips costing a staggering £, on average.Taxpayers Alliance policy analyst Ben Ramanauskas blasted the huge costs that “ultimately achieved nothing”.He said: “These negotiations were important and it is obviously right that, as prime minister, Theresa May met with European leaders.“However, costs should be kept low and that taxpayers money is spent wisely. Theresa May should have used cheaper options such as commercial flights, where appropriate.“Taxpayers will be disappointed that the Prime Minister was spending so much money on hotels and restaurants and, ultimately, achieved nothing.”May, , racked up over , miles visiting  cities in  EU countries mainly in the UK PM’s personal plane RAF Voyager – dubbed May Force One.The Airbus  was brought in by Cameron at a cost of £million and he claimed it would save £, a year in the cost of private charters in December .But figures show it cost taxpayers around £, per trip and the -seater craft left a huge carbon footprint over the  month period.Unsurprisingly Brussels was the top destination with  visits – or once every six weeks – followed by Berlin which she travelled to six times and Paris on three.Belgium, Germany and France were also the top three countries she saw with  visits to Belgium, seven to France and eight to Germany.It included  bilateral talks with EU nations’ leaders,  EU council meetings as well as EU Commission meets a Brexit speech and other major summits.May also splurged £million on trips outside the EU over the same period.A UK Government spokesman said: “It’s the Prime Minister’s job to represent the United Kingdom internationally, including at major international events like the European Council and NATO Summit.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl 17 who cant left
story: NewsGirl, , who cant be left alone as she has  seizures a day forced to quit schoolFreya Williams, from Plymouth, has al neurological disorder [FND], non-epileptic attack disorder [NEAD], postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome [POTS], hyper-mobility syndrome, chronic fatigue and scoliosisShareCommentsByKatie TimmsAlice Richardson:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video teen-who-quit-school-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old who canapost be left alone because she has between  and  seizures a day has had to drop out of school, has been praised for her remarkable optimism. When she was little, Freya Williams, from Plymouth, suffered with severe back pain but wanted to eventually join the British Army, so she pushed through the pain and continued to train for the forces. Freya went on to pick the appropriate A-Levels and was well on her way to achieving her le-long dream. But her hopes were shattered after a visit to the doctor in October last year, which led to her being diagnosed with a number of health conditions.   The -year-old now relies on a wheelchair and cannot be left alone as she suffers between  and  seizures a day, which led to her having to abandon her studies, , reports PlymouthLive .But despite this set-back, Freya remains positive and wants to raise awareness of hidden health conditions and even hopes to write a book to inspire other unwell teenagers.    Freya has al neurological disorder , non-epileptic attack disorder , postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome , hyper-mobility syndrome, chronic fatigue and scoliosis. She said the long list of conditions have caused ious mental health issues as well, but the teen hopes by speaking out she will help other people who are going through a similar situation. The former Heleaposs School pupil said: I have suffered horric back pain for around three years and in October I got diagnosed with scoliosis. This is a curvature of the spine, so my spine is the shape of a aposc’.    This was pretty tough to deal with as my le long dream was to join the army, but I continued to train for the forces and and do my A-levels. Freya also has many allergies and after her GP tried her on a neuropathic pain killer called Duloxetine, she ended up severely ill and was paralysed from the waist down for around  days. She continued: I also had very little movement on my upper body. I was like a young child, I had to be fed, showered, carried. I felt like I’d lost everything. After  days I got discharged from the hospital after finally walking with a lot of aid. But around a week later, Freya was back in hospital, paralysed again, when she got another diagnosis. She was told she had FND and NEAD, which Freya said canapost really be fixed other than having intensive physiotherapy and rehabilitation, which often has no guarantee that you will be able to get back to the way you were prior to getting sick. Freya said when she goes to bed at night, she doesnapost know which part of her body she will be unable to move the following day, which sometimes makes it dficult to carry out daily activities, such as eating.    She said: Living with FND means that when I go to bed I’m the evening I don’t know which part of my body won’t work the next day - so I often can’t swallow foods, I struggle with walking and I went from being army fit to using a wheel chair when I leave the house. Freya also gets memory loss, constant nausea, joint pain and other debilitating symptoms due to the condition.Freya said due to her POTS, which causes her to faint due to her heart rate being really high and her blood pressure being really low, that she recognises dferent places by what the ceiling looks like.The teenager has spent around two months in Derrord Hospital so far this year and for many of those weeks she has been in a state of paralysis. Freya has praised the phenomenal health care professionals that look after her during her stays. She said: I’ve had to leave my job and my education and basically put everything on hold. As a result of all of these conditions I now suffer very badly with chronic fatigue along with a lot of mental illnesses that are very dficult to cope with. The NHS and Livewell staff are just so phenomenal and it is safe to say that without them I would probably still be in a state or paralysis. This and amazing support from my wonderful family and close friends. Since I have gotten sick my le has been turned around. But I now see the world in a new light and I have become a person that I am proud to be.    When you are chronically ill you can wake up some days and not see the point of le anymore, and I think it is so acceptable to feel that way because it sucks, and I feel like that a lot, but I am trying to channel my illness into a positive thing. I met some wonderful NHS staff that inspired me to go into nursing. I have also found an inner voice since getting ill. I am so passionate about raising awareness for chronic illnesses and mental illness and sharing the passivities of my experiences and what I have learnt this year. I try to stay as positive as I can, it’s inevitable to have the bad days and to not be OK all of the time. There is no amount of medicine that is going to make you happy, you’ve got to just try and stay positive and stay upbeat and do everything that you can to make it feel a little bit better and a little bit easier.

title: almost half tory members want
story: NewsAlmost HALF of Tory members want to reduce Muslims coming to UK, shock poll showsEXCLUSIVE: A poll for Hope Not Hate has alarming revelations about the , Conservative members wholl choose our next Prime MinisterShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN NewsYouGov questioned more than  Conservative Party members"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt have been challenged to tackle Tory Islamophobia after a shocking poll revealed the extent of anti-Muslim sentiment in the party. The results of the YouGov poll for Hope Not Hate also show more than two thirds of those questionedbelieve the lie that parts of Britain operate under Sharia law. The poll shows % also believe the hood, bolstered by Donald Trump, that there are no go areas for non-Muslims in the UK. The chair of the Conservative Muslim Forum has pledged to rip up his -year-old membership of the partyBoris Johnson - who described Muslim women as bank robbers and letter boxes makes it to No . title: mirror readers share brexit views
story: NewsMirror readers share Brexit views on third anniversary of EU referendumIn Huddersfield and Hull, in Devon and Bristol, Edinburgh and Brecon, pairs of people matched by our ground-breaking Britain Talks project met across the political ide.ShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsHendrik de Jong and Humaira Ali discuss their conflicting views "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain stopped shouting and started listening yesterday and no milkshakes were thrown. Pairs of people matched by our ground-breaking Britain Talks project met across the political ide and learned to listen. Fittingly they chatted as communities nationwide reached out to each other for the third year of the Great Get Together in memory of murdered MP Jo Cox. The Mirror partnered with theand regional newspapers across Reach PLC to find the widest possible audience. More than , readers were brave enough to sign up, and hundreds finally met their political opposite yesterday in Huddersfield and Hull, Devon and Bristol, Edinburgh and Brecon. Three years after the EU referendum result, the aim was to escape our own social bubbles, and to share a cup of tea or have a pint in the sunshine with someone of opposing opinions.    Our matches joined tens of thousands who attended events remembering Jo, who was killed a right-wing extemist, and honouring her belief that we have “more in common than that which ides us”. Arch Brexiteer Claire Milne, , had a robust exchanges in Edinburgh with ardent Remainer company director John Birchmore. It left them keen to chat again. Afterwards Claire laughed: “No milkshakes were thrown.” Our couples aired their strong views about Brexit , immigration, climate change, Donald Trump, austerity and crime. They came together over the NHS, their local football team, public transport and most of all the need to talk to each other. Described as “political Tinder”, Britain Talks is based on My Country Talks – an initiative from German news website Zeit Online. The original experiment has been repeated in Italy, Norway, Denmark, Switzerland and Austria, as Europe confronts its isions.  When we began the project  weeks ago, our poll showed Brexit was the issue people felt ided them most – at %. Immigration followed at %, left-right politics at % and wealth at %. The same poll showed % felt our country was ided – with % arguing with family or friends about Brexit several times a week. One in four felt angry with people who voted the opposite way to them on Brexit day, and % said people had become less tolerant since. But our polling also showed % wishing the UK was more united. And % liked the idea of chatting to someone with an opposing view without anyone losing their temper. In a Britain re-polarised since Brexit by a lack of progress in Parliament, the EU elections and now the Tory leadership race, finding , people prepared to meet is a symbol of hope. Here are snapshots of some of the Britain Talks discussions...Read more about Britain Talks at mirror britaintalksLondon     Amid the sociable swirl at a London community festival, two very dferent people smile out of one large chequered photo frame. The words “we’ve got more in common” wrapped in large letters around the faces of Hendrik de Jong, , and Humaira Ali, . Ex-police officer Hendrik supports the Brexit Party and wants Britain to leave the EU immediately. Humaira is a Lib Dem councillor for Southwark. They met at the Great British Get Together happening on London’s Bankside – a festival inspired by the work of murdered MP Jo Cox. Humaira says: “I think there’s a lot we agree onyou take out Brexit – health, housing, social responsibility and the environment. Hendrik adds: “We both believe in equality.” The pair even agreed to meet up again. Hendrik says: “After Holland joined the EU my family lost money on their pensions. We were % worse off afterwards and had no vote on it. British politicians now need to get a better deal for Britain.” But Humaira says: “We already have the best deal. Margaret Thatcher negotiated it years ago. We’re not in Schengen and we don’t have the euro.” Huddersfield  When Phil Wood meets Adam Rana in a cafe, the Remainer is worried that Adam’s entrepreneurial side will make his views hard to swallow. But after meeting, community development consultant Phil, , realises that despite their political dferences his concerns are misplaced. Self-confessed “hopeless idealist” Phil says: “I think we want the same thing really – a better world where people take more care of each other, take more responsibility and are prepared to go out of their way rather than just think about themselves.” Adam, , who trades over the internet, says: “I’m a firm believer in leaving the EU because it will help Britain’s trading position.” Adam, a full-time carer for his we, believes a thriving economy will create better public services.But Phil warns it could lead to “dog eat dog”. Adam says of the meeting: “It has opened my views up to someone ’s way of thinking. I feel the focus is on ‘me, me ,me’.” And he laments the way the Government shuns the elderly, forcing them to rely on charity. “It seems a case of ‘Thanks for the service, we don’t want to know about you’.” Manchester  One is a die-hard Brexiteer, the other a dedicated Remainer. “I’m sick of being called a Remoaner when all I want is a better future for my kids,” says catering assistant Donna Chadwick, , a mum of two teenage boys from Heywood. Terence Farrand, , a semi-retired builder, has lived in Europe but is clear we should be out of the EU, with no second vote. “If we do that, democracy is finished,” he warns. For Terence, married with four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren, immigration means pressure on the NHS. “You can’t get an appointment when you need one,” he says. Donna says: “Yes, services are struggling but that’s more about investment.” But when Donna and Terence, from Whitefield, meet over wine and coffee, they find a shared love of Bury Football Club – and agree the NHS needs cash. “It’s been good to have someone to listen to what I’ve got to say, without being shouted down,” says Donna, as they decide to meet up again this week. Terence agrees. “I have strong opinions but we live in a world where people are scared to express them, or to speak to someone with dferent views.” Brecon Beacons  In the foothills of the Brecon Beacons, Annette Lloyd and Emily Durrant are searching for common ground in a canal-side cafe. Emily was not even born when Annette started her first job in a factory, and they are never going to agree on Brexit. But there is much to unite them... Emily, , juggles two young children and three jobs, including her role as a Green Party county councillor. Meanwhile, Annette, , toils on nights as a support worker and helps to look after her grandchildren and elderly relatives. Both agree low wages and austerity mean families are under pressure. Emily, who also works for the National Trust, says: “The economy doesn’t work for families. Wages are just too low.” Emily, from Llangorse, Powys, is a committed Remainer. Annette, , favours Brexit. “It’ll get the factories working again,” she says. But Emily finds common ground with Annette, from Llandeilo Graban, over the NHS. “We’ve been sold down the river,” they agree. Before going their separate ways, Annette and Emily hug and laugh. “When you look at the bigger picture,” Annette says, “we’re very similar.” Stoke  In the leafy hamlet of Stockton Brook, near Stoke- on-Trent, it’s clear William Alcock and Louise Adams both feel passionately about their city. William, , served in the Army for  years before joining the police and Louise, , is a freelance artist who works in the ceramics industry. And William, now retired, doesn’t hesitate to air his views about Brexit. He says: “We are spending £million a day to be in the EU. That is what we are paying the thieves in Brussels. They have taken away our sovereignty. “We are losing control of this country and we are losing control of our cultures.” Louise believes we should stay in the EU. “It will allow us to build on love, peace and friendships,” she says. “Being part of the EU has allowed us to work together, share cultures and ideas.” Louise believes that with the right investment refugees can settle here successfully but William is concerned about the pressure it puts on the NHS. But they agree they both want what’s best for their beloved country.

title: newsnights emily maitlis slammed letting
story: NewsNewsnights Emily Maitlis slammed for letting dog sleep on seat of packed trainEXCLUSIVE - The presenter and journalist, , was seen travelling with her whippet, Moody, on a busy Great Western train to London Paddington this afternoonShareCommentsByAmy Coles:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsBBC Newsnight Presenter Emily Maitlis let her dog curl up on a train seat "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNewsnight host Emily Maitlis has been hounded for letting her dog sleep on a seat on packed train. The presenter and journalist, , was seen travelling with her whippet, Moody, on a busy Great Western train to London Paddington this afternoon. There were few empty seats but she let her dog curl up next to her. Other paying passengers had to look ­where for a place to sit. A witness said: “I was really surprised to see the dog on the seat. There wasn’t even a mat or newspaper underneath it. “For someone who is very much in the public eye, who holds politicians to account, I would have expected her to behave better. “When I boarded the train it was really busy. A lady was looking for a seat and ended up sitting behind Emily and not on a seat with a table, where there is more room.  “Some people chose to stand, as there were few spare seats. It shows a lack of respect for other passengers to feel it appropriate for dogs to sit on seats meant for passengers. “It’s a question of courtesy and consideration for others. The dog should have been on the floor. It could have been dirty or could have had ticks or fleas.” The witness, going from Reading, Berks to London, said Maitlis’s dog slept on the Penzance to London service for at least  minutes before Paddington. Last week, Maitlis, one of ­Britain’s most respected interviewers, was criticised over her handling of the televised Tory leadership debate with hundreds of BBC viewers accusing her of losing control of the candidates and failing to get answers. Bruce Williamson, of the ­Railfuture campaign, said expensive train fares mean “people who have paid for a ticket must come first”.  He added: “I’m surprised a conductor didn’t say something about it. I’m a dog lover, but dogs on trains are essentially luggage and second-class ­citizens to humans. Seats should be reserved for first and ­foremost for humans. “It just highlights the level of overcrowding on our railways and the shortage of seats.” A railway passenger group said Maitlis broke one of the network operators rules. Fraser Pithie, of the Campaign for Rail, said: “The rules do not give animals any right to take up seats. Dogs must remain on the floor. Even guide dogs are not allowed on seats. A train guard should have spoken to her.”  A spokesman from Great Western confirmed the company does allow people to bring animals on their trains but said they are never allowed on seats. National Rail conditions say: “Animals are not allowed on seats in any circumstances” and warn a charge could be madeanimals occupy seats. In a statement, Maitlis said: “There was no one without a seat looking to sit down. “The dog was under the table for the first three hours of the journey whilst four people sat down at it. He came on to the seat for the last  minutes of the journey when the seat next to me became free.”

title: three years after eu referendum
story: NewsThree years after the EU referendum Britain is more ided than ever on BrexitAs Westminster fails to find solutions, more people favour “no deal” or a second referendumShareByRyan Fletcher:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsStuart Lilland Nick Thompson both from Hull, discuss Brexit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Three years after the EU referendum, Britain is more ided than ever on Brexit .As Westminster fails to find solutions, more people favour “no deal” or a second referendum. But left-right politics, Scottish independence, trans rights and veganism are also among the topics which we are ided over. Hull voted by .% to .% to leave the EU. Locals Nick Thompson and Stuart Lill dfer over Brexit, but agree politicians are failing to bridge the ide. Marketing worker Nick, , is a Remainer, while Stuart, , a carer for his autistic son, is a Leaver. Stuart says: “It’s very much a case of, ‘You must be a racistyou voted Brexit’. Tell that to my Polish better half and Polish kids. “I’m still a Brexiteer, I just care about my country.” Nick says: “It’s wrong that people on the Leave side are labelled like that. Part of the trouble is representation. You don’t feel represented and I don’t feel represented either.  “It’s just I don’t think that situation will change by leaving the EU.” Stuart and Nick both feel public services are being starved of resources but dfer on the causes. Nick says: “Austerity was a choice by the UK Government and nothing to do with Europe. “Some say it had to be made, but it didn’t. When you think they can’t cut any more, they cut more and more.“As one of the richest countries in the world, we shouldn’t have foodbanksall over the place.We shouldn’t have all these people sleeping on the streets.” Stuart thinks immigration has added to the pressures on public services. He says: “You can’t argue that the numbers that have come haven’t added to the burden on things such as housing and hospital waiting lists. “Populism is rising across Europe because of the hatred of the EU.” Nick worries the power will go from the EU to the UK Government which is “a lot less trustworthy than Brussels”. Stuart agrees: “I don’t think there’s a political party out there that is really doing a very good job.” Nick says: “We both feel politically homeless. Politics now is a shambles.” Devon  * A clash over climate change got a cool reaction from Green Party voter Adrian Allery when UKIP supporter Andre Savini said blaming CO for global warming was hot air. Proving it is possible to disagree very agreeably, -year-old antiques shop manager Andre and deep-sea ship pilot Adrian, , shared their views over a pint in Honiton, Devon. Leave voter Andre argued: “It’s a myth that CO is the main driver in climate change.” Remain voter Adrian thought the two-hour pub chat raised interesting points. “But I simply do not agree with Andre that climate change is a scam to raise taxes, that big pharma is toxic or that the EU is an evil Stalinist empire,” he said. But even these unlikely lads found common ground. They agreed faith schools should be abolished and the first-past-the-post political system is not fit for purpose. Despite his Italian roots, Andre believes immigration has to be controlled, saying he supports UKIP because “mainstream parties are just there for big business”. While Adrian said, “I felt Andre cherry picks facts that back his theories. I was glad we met, I’d do it again.” Bristol  When two Bristol locals went on a debating date in the park, they found plenty of common ground. The sun smiled on -year-old electrician James Pierce and NHS administrator Jane Westmead, , and they found their dferences melting away.Poetry lover Jane said: “It went really, really well. James was very honest, and we were still chatting away hours later when we bumped into Bristol’s Labour mayor Marvin Rees in the park and he joined in the discussions.”Leave voter James said he was expecting Jane to be shouty and unwilling to listen, but instead she was fun and open-minded. He explained: “Although we disagree on many issues, we have the same goals. Jane voted for Remain, but she respects the result and neither of us want a second referendum.” Left-voting Jane admits she had preconceived notions about staunch Tory James. But she said: “We both love the NHS but think it’s very inefficient. London  Retired local government officer Ken Hickford and charity worker Billy Beckett met in a North London Italian restaurant for their debate. Ken, , wants Britain out of Europe but Billy, , thinks unity makes us stronger and more secure. Ken reckons refugees should get sanctuary but be sent home when their nation is back on its feet as the UK’s infrastructure is close to collapse. Billy thinks, by then, they may bring all sorts of value to us and austerity may be more to blame for the problems. They are polar opposites but Ken said: “I liked Billy’s enthusiasm. He seems to believe in politicians and our conversation did give me a boost.” Billy liked talking to someone with dferent views. He said: “Social media confirms our own biases. This has been a way to step out of it.” Liverpool  Remainer Michelle Bennett and committed Brexiteer Dave Jones live just a few miles away from each other. But, on paper, they are poles apart. It isn’t long before Michelle, , a trained social worker, and retired community nurse Dave, , are setting the world to rights over a coffee. Mum-of-one Michelle voted to Leave but has since become a Remainer – worried about the prospect of no deal – and wants a second referendum. “So much has changed since then,” she says. Dave, a mild-mannered father of four from Wavertree, disagrees. He said: “We need to respect the result.” But, both are clear the NHS needs to be valued and we should help refugees. Michelle lives in Toxteth – where Dave was born – and they leave, laughing, and admitting they’d loved the experience. Dave even offered Michelle a lt home. Edinburgh  They met as strangers on a bridge coming from opposite sides. John Birchmore, , is a company director and such an ardent Remainer he moved his company’s centre of operations to Latvia and has a new Irish passport. John’s campaigning for a People’s Vote and even has politics discussions with his postie, who decried the EU as non-democratic while delivering his postal vote. “He failed to see the irony,” says John. Claire Milne, , is a Jacob Rees-Mogg-loving, Tory-voting Brexiteer. At home, she has been told she’s only allowed to speak three sentences of politics a day because, “I tend to go on a bit”. As they settle down to a cool drink in the shade of Edinburgh’s Princes Street Gardens, their conversation heats up until there is table thumping and exclamations of “cobblers!” and “b*****ks!”. John says: “There were lots of myths pedalled by Brexiteers about not being able to sell crooked cucumbers.” Claire retorts: “Bananas!” It’s a robust  minutes. At times, their voices rise higher than a nearby pipes and drums contest. But, at the end, both are keen to chat again. “It’s great to listen to someone who is well informed and can be challenged on details,” John says. Claire laughs: “And no milkshakes were thrown.”

title: i went undercover told take
story: NewsI went undercover - and was told to take explosives hidden in teddy bears to schoolDavid Rupert was drawn into the dark and dangerous world of terrorism to become a double agent working for the FBI inside the IRA - this is his incredible story in his own wordsShareComments"ByDavid Rupert :,  JUN NewsDavid Rupert who infiltrated the Real IRA in Ireland while working for the FBI "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was , and I’d been living in West Florida while running my trucking company. I was in Tampa with friends when I heard folk music coming from an Irish and Scottish bar, The Harp  Thistle. I liked the music, so I went in. There one night, I met this beautul, lively woman named Linda. We started dating and I soon learned she was heavily involved with Noraid, the US political wing of the Provisional IRA. I didn’t know much about the Northern Ireland conflict, but feigned interest because I liked Linda. She invited me to Ireland and I accepted. We drove up to Sligo and Donegal on the west coast – Linda knew the owners of pro-IRA bars and they all knew her by her first name.    One of the owners, Joe O’Neill, was a long-time IRA man and he took a liking to me and taught me about Irish history. Linda and I broke up soon afterwards, but I was hooked on Ireland by then and went back by myself to meet Joe and other IRA men.I didn’t know it at the time, but the Irish police were photographing me with IRA members and sent the photos to the FBI.One day an FBI agent showed up at my trucking company office. I said I didn’t know about anything illegal, which was the truth, but he insisted on coming back to ask questions. He then said the FBI would pay for me and my new girlfriend, Maureen, to fly to Ireland when we wanted, in exchange for small pieces of information about the IRA.    As I didn’t know anything, I felt I might as well let the FBI pay for our holidays. So we would go back and forth to Ireland and give the FBI very little. Then one day, Joe invited me to the room he used for IRA meetings, which was above his pub. He said he wanted me to smuggle explosive parts from the US, and gave me the address of a primary school where I should send them – the plastic explosives were to be hidden in teddy bears, detonating cord disguised as skipping rope, and electronic parts hidden in radios. This made me flinch – the idea of sending explosives to a school. I said I would, but I passed on the info to the FBI, and soon the spying operation became more serious. I wanted to move to Ireland anyway, and the FBI agreed to pay for the lease on a pub on the Irish border, near Joe’s bar. My bar quickly became a gathering point for IRA members and the information started to come in.  I liked the customers, but some moments shocked me – like watching a granny bouncing a young boy on her knee and telling him some day he would shoot policemen in the North. Pretty soon the FBI asked me to meet MI, which was keen to have spies in the IRA groups that were opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process. I flew to London for a debrief with an MI agent, and soon I was reporting to them as well. Then, in August , the Real IRA set off a car bomb in Omagh, which killed  civilians, including a mother nine months pregnant with twins. Later, Maureen and I watched a documentary about children injured in the Omagh bomb, one of whom was blinded. It was devastating.  I had to remind myself these were the people I was dealing with. There was a tendency to see them as friends, but I also had to find those other feelings at the back of that – revulsion and disgust for what was happening to innocent people. Then I was introduced to the Real IRA’s leader, Mickey McKevitt, along with several of his top men. He liked me straight away, and I liked him. He was easy to talk to and was enthusiastic about American fund-raising money and my ability to get weapons and bomb parts in the US.Over time, I learned he had a sleeper agentin the US who would be brought to the UK when the time was right to shoot Tony Blair , or some other high-level British establishment figure.I met the sleeper several times in Massachusetts and he was keen toget weapons moving to Ireland.Eventually, Mickey suggested I sit on the Real IRA’s army council. I wouldn’t have voting rights, but I could very to US supporters that their money was being well spent and be able to report back on weapons and bomb parts needed by the Real IRA.The army council meetings were held at a farmer’s cottage in the mountains on the border, where the farmer’s we would make us tea, while he discussed bombings in England and assassinations of police officers.I would send detailed emails to the FBI and MI of what was happening.My scariest moment came when I attended the ‘engineering’ orbomb-making meetings.I brought along encryption software for the team that had been doctored by MI.  One of the top bomb makers was very suspicious and said that it might have been tampered with. My heart was racing and I was sweating. I was petried and couldn’t sleep that night. I was really on edge, wonderingthe Real IRA would find out that the encryption software had been compromised. What would happen to me and Maureenthey did  I knew about the torture and death that came to other IRA informers. There was a case in which a woman was beaten to death by three IRA members, while with another informer, they set up a roadblock, shot him in the back of the head and rolled his car into the canal. The police didn’t find his body for two years. That would have been my fate.  I began to wonder how much longer we could stay in this le. Mickey told me he was looking for a foreign sponsor to supply them with weapons and was interested in Saddam Hussein.I told MI, who were excited and saw it as an opportunity to ensnare the Real IRA.It was agreed with MI that I would testy against some of the Real IRA leadership, and in one day there were arrests of leaders in the south of Ireland, the north, and the US. I was flown to a US airbase in Britain, as I was due to testy against three Real IRA council members who had set up meetings with Saddam Hussein’s agents . Then I flew on the British royal jet to testy against Mickey McKevitt, who was arrested at his home. He wasn’t one bit happy to see me this time, and glared at me. I was nervous at the beginning of the trial – there were lots of TV cameras outside the court, and army snipers on the roof of the courtroom. Mickey’s barrister cross-examined me for two weeks. It was gruelling.  After I finally finished testying, the SAS took me by Hercules plane out of Ireland forever. The most stressful part was after I had finished testying and ed to the US in hiding. I had all this adrenaline running through me for years. Suddenly I wasn’t living on the edge any more and couldn’t handle my emotions. I went on anti-depressants and anti-anxiety drugs, Maureen went on them too. We couldn’t adjust to this new passive world after so many years undercover, but I eventually learned to get on with le and enjoy myself. Mickey McKevitt was jailed for  years and I know he will never forgive me. Still, after the Omagh bomb, I have no regrets about what I did.  I also earned millions of dollars from the FBI, but I can never work again because the Real IRA would catch up with me. I loved being a spy, but I will be looking over my shoulder for the rest of my le.- Get % off  The Accidental Spy  with offer code R Plus PP. Call    or order online at Mirror Books

title: 3 years black student university
story: NewsMy  years as a black student at university - and why I would never do it againKent Caribbean Union co-founder Jessica Mayne reveals how tough le was for her on the Canterbury campusShareCommentsByJessica Mayne:,  JUN NewsThe student revealed her tough experiences "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA recent graduate from the University of Kent has told of her dficult experiences as a black student.Jessica Mayne completed a religious studies degree at the universityaposs Canterbury campus but has now opened up about the challenges of leaving home, enduring racial slurs and an awful experience in her first month of studying, Kent Live reports.Year  They say the first year of university is the best. I couldnapost relate. The University of Kent in Canterbury was my number one choice. While attending an applicant day, I was immediately put at ease. The campus was beautul, my desired course— religious studies — was being taught by world class scholars, and it was not too far from my home in Bromley. I instantly knew it was  meant to be.    It is, however, an understatement to say that in September   I was nervous. I dreamt and imagined what this new phase of my le would entail but had no idea what to expect.The numerous Netflix films I watched, exhibiting the American college experience would never prepare me for the journey I was about to embark on.“We hate you you f******  n*****” was the racial abuse directed at me by my housemate in my halls of residence.  My housemates took personal offence to the fact that I did not want to drink and go out with them. I was friendly but reserved because I was still acclimatising to le away from home. Additionally, getting drunk every night and being asked to clean up vomit was not my idea of fun.  It was only the first couple of months of university, I wanted to take my time. I had worked so hard to get into university. It goes without saying that I quickly became the least favourite person in the house. Living in the most aesthetically pleasing accommodation, Turing College,  on campus — jokingly referred to by some as Beverly Hills — could not compensate for living with people I did not get on with. My bedroom not only became the place where I had to store my kitchenware, it became my sanctuary. However, even my room couldnapost shield me from the unedying sight of  strangers using my shared toilet with the door wide open! It is a notorious attitude that because the first year does not contribute to your final degree, you do not have to work as hard. Whilst many of  my first year counterparts were partying nightly, I was determined to excel academically from the outset.      Consequently, I was a first year student stressing out like a final year one. Year  Carrying the weight of isolation that the  first year brought, I feared that my bedroom, my place of refuge, had become a cage, locking me away from all of the enjoyable experiences that the University of Kent had to offer. I did not regret working hard in my first year because that is what I set out to do.  I did, however, feel that consuming myself solely with my degree was unhealthy and not conducive to forming meaningful relationships and enjoying my university experience outside of academia.    As a British-Jamaican person, I noticed that a wider isolation  existed among students of caribbean heritage at university. In response to this,  I co-founded a society, with Louise Mayne, where  such students could be represented and elevated. This society, Kent Caribbean Union , aims to rewrite the narrative by educating, raising aspirations and inspiring all students to fulfill their potential. It was, therefore, to my dismay that KCU had to fight for the right to exist. Even the backdrop of the th anniversary year of Windrush and the infamous Windrush scandal would not motivate some members of the student body  to acknowledge our right to be represented. Second year was the year where I really had to strengthen my time management skills. In addition to my responsibilities to the society, I  devoted time to being an academic mentor and outreach ambassador. By this stage I no longer lived on campus, but privately rented of off campus   with my sister and two other friends  — whom I had met during the previous year. The courses we studied were religious studies, maths and law. The novelty of not living under your parent’s roof soon wears off as you become burdened with the responsibilities that come with independent living. Luckily, I moved to Canterbury from Bromley and so was never too far away toto home comforts. Year  With Canterbury Cathedral within a stoneaposs throw of my house, I was ashamed that by my final year I still I had not managed to visit it. I began to explore the beauty of the city. Walking down the quaint cobbled streets served as a constant reminder of the rich heritage of this city. The contrast between the lively and progressive student city with the historic sights and buildings never ceases to fascinate me. This amazement, however, quickly dwindled when I noticed the visible homelessness, something I did not see as often in Bromley. Canterbury is home to three dferent universities, accommodating thousands of UK and international students. It is evident that much of the  ersity present in the city can largely be attributed to the substantial student population.    I always wonder what Canterbury would look like without such student residents  This year was the most rewarding as the society soared to new heights. At the Kent Student Awards , KCU, was awarded ‘Group of the Year’ and ‘Outstanding International Multicultural Initiative of the Year.’ We were also shortlisted for Outstanding Contribution to Equality, Diversity and Inclusivity, being the only group to be shortlisted in more than one category. The awards ceremony celebrated other inspiring students who are contributing to changes in government policy, campaigning against social injustices and raising awareness of illnesses. Considering this, not only is there evidently hope for my generation, but I am proud to have unapologetically fought for something I believe in. Whilst my three years in Canterbury have been physically, mentally and emotionally draining, they have built my character,confidence and inner strength. So would I do it again  No. Am I happy that I did it  % yes. I have left Canterbury, not just with a st class degree, but with a better sense of self. University of Kent statement A spokesman for the university said: We do not tolerate any form of racism or racist abuse. We are committed to the promotion of ersity and inclusivity within the University community, and this commitment is underpinned in our Institutional Strategic Plan. Through the Student Charter that we developed with Kent Union, the University has also committed to the fair and equal treatment of every person, and to ersity and inclusivity in its student and staff community.    Our students are also committed to treating fellow students, University staff, visitors, neighbours and all people equally and respectfully, regardless of gender, religion, community background, nationality, race ethnic origin, disability, marital or other status, responsibilities, sexual orientation or age.   In order to ensure all students are fully informed when it comes to treating everyone with dignity and respect we created the aposExpect Respect @ Kent’ e-learning module which all students must complete within six months of arriving at Kent.

title: around 16 atms day converted
story: NewsAround  ATMs a day converted from free to charging harming vulnerable the mostEXCLUSIVE - Figures show nearly , fee-charging ATMs appeared in the first four months of this yearShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  JUN NewsIn some areas, more than one in three ATMs charge, while in worst-hit places, it is close to half"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround  cash machines a day are being converted from free to charging – with US firms among those coining it in. Figures show nearly , fee-charging ATMs appeared in the first four months of this year. In some areas, more than one in three ATMs charge, while in worst-hit places, it is close to half. Many are in less well-off areas where people can least afford the fees. Caroline Abrahams, director of Age UK, said: “ATMs that charge are penalising the poorest pensioners.” Gareth Shaw, of consumer group Which , has said it risks harming “the most vulnerable the hardest”, adding: “A regulator is desperately needed.”  The situation has been worsened by bank and building society branches closing. Which  said in April that , had shut last year or were due to this year. Figures from Link, which connects most cash machines, show there were more than , ATMs in December, of which , charged. By April, the number was ,. Operators blame the rise on a cut by Link to the interchange fee paid by banks for running free-to-use ATMs. Most affected ATMs are run by Texas-based Cardtronics, which has said it is likely to convert , more machines in the coming months.  NoteMachine, bought in  by a US firm, is considering converting up to ,. John Howells, head of Link, which has an app that locates free machines, acknowledged ATM firms “often make more money from pay ATMs than free”. Cardtronics said: “The fees directly reflect the sustainable viability of each machine, including servicing it.” NoteMachine did not respond.

title: bride sheds five stone goes
story: NewsBride-to-be sheds five stone and goes from size  to size  in just four monthsSophie Matheson from Nottinghamshire has dropped five dress sizes after committing to a new fitness programme in the lead up to her weddingShareCommentsByHannah MitchellPippa Allen-Kinross:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsSophie dropped five stone in the four months before her wedding day "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA primary school teacher dropped an impressive five stone in just four months before her wedding day after embarking on a new fitness regime. Sophie Matheson, , dropped from a size  to a size  in just  weeks after getting in touch with a personal trainer. She got married in October and has since lost another stone, taking her total weight loss to six stone. Sophie, who works at Intake Farm Primary School in Mansfield, said: I had reached a point where I was dreading my wedding day. I was anxious about the photos, how I would look and feel in my dress and what others would think of me, and knew I had to do something to make a positive change.    She got in touch with local personal trainer Luke Hewitt after seeing some of his work on social media. Sophie, who lives in Ollerton, in Nottinghamshire, said she was nervous before her first session but was put at ease by Lukeaposs team. I started to see changes really quickly and began to develop a love for the gym, she told Nottinghamshire Live . She trained with Luke three times a week for  weeks in the lead up to her wedding day, with a programme that included a combination of cardiovascular exercise and weight training as well as a diet plan. Sophie said: My job as a primary school teacher can be quite stressful and fast paced and my diet before starting the programme reflected that. A typical day would have previously started with good intentions, with Weetabix for breakfast and fruit for my mid-morning snack, but then it would start to go downhill. Lunchtime would arrive and the staff room at work would be full of cakes and biscuits, so I’d help myself to those before grabbing a pre-packed wrap or sandwich for lunch. After work, I’d go to the shop and get crisps, sweets and chocolates and binge eat and then dinner would be something like wedges and a burger. We would also indulge in takeaways several times a week.”  Before she lost the weight, Sophie took  tablets a day for endometriosis and irritable bowel syndrome , but now she doesnapost take any medication at all. Sophie is a vegetarian and now keeps to a diet plan tailored for her. A typical day would consist of porridge or an omelette for breakfast, Quorn chilli, rice and salad for lunch and halloumi and vegetables kebabs with curried lentils for dinner, as well as ious snacks to keep her going throughout the day. She said: At first I couldnapost believe how much food I was able to eat. Iaposve tried every fad diet going so feeling satisfied rather than deprived made a huge dference to my motivation and sticking power. That, combined with my gym sessions, has completely changed my le for the better. I used to make excuses not to go out to social events and didnapost feel comfortable in anything I tried on. Now, I’m happier in all aspects of le: I’m more confident at work, have an even better relationship with my husband and I’m happier on holiday because I can wear what I want without feeling uncomfortable.”  By her wedding day, Sophie had got her weight down to  stone and wore a size  wedding dress. She has continued training and lost a further stone. She said: I felt amazing on my wedding day, and I definitely have Luke to thank for that, but for me this wasn’t just about losing weight for my wedding. It was about becoming happier and healthier for good and I know I’ll never go back to my old habits because I feel so much better and coming off my medication speaks volumes.  “The gym has become my therapy and no matter what mood I arrive in, I always leave feeling on top of the world.

story: NewsFrozen sperm bank could be set up in space says say scientistsScientists say the opportunity to create a reserve outside of Earth is a distinct possibilityShareCommentsBySally Wardle:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsScientists say more research needs to be done "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSperm banks could one day be set up in space, scientists have predicted. Frozen samples that were exposed to microgravity conditions and those kept in normal conditions appear to keep similar characteristics, according to the results of a small study, the Press Association has reported. The results of the research suggest frozen sperm could be sent into space and open the possibility of creating a human sperm bank outside of Earth. But more research is needed to fully understand the effect of space conditions, scientists have said.    The study was presented at the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology annual meeting in Vienna, Austria.The scientists conducting the study said little is known about the effect of dferent gravity levels on sperm.Dr Montserrat Boada, from Dexeus Womenaposs Health in Barcelona, said: Some studies suggest a signicant decrease in the motility of human fresh sperm sample. But nothing has been reported on the possible effects of gravitational dferences on frozen human gametes, in which state they could be transported from Earth to space.    The researchers used sperm from  healthy donors, exposing some of the samples to microgravity using a small aerobatic aircraft.The samples were then analysed for concentration, motility and DNA fragmentation - tests which are all performed to check for fertility.No signicant dferences were found between the samples kept on the ground and those exposed to microgravity, according to the study.

story: NewsopinionGirl, , and little sister, , taking on fast-food giants over plastic toysElla McEwan and her sister Caitlin were inspired to act after a family trip to Burger King - Their campaign has already attracted , signatures – and countingShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionOn tomorrow night’s War on Plastic on BBC, the problem is laid bare showing millions of barely played with toys all adding to our mountain of plastic waste "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDespite our best efforts to clear up the plastic waste which has polluted the oceans, the responsibility to ensure we fully change our relationship with single-use items may now fall to the next generation. But the future is in safe handsnine-year-old Ella McEwan and her sister Caitlin, seven, are anything to go by. After learning at school how rubbish is endangering sea le, the eco-aware pair from Southampton set up an online petition for fast-food giants to stop putting plastic toys in children’s meal boxes. Inspired to act after a family trip to Burger King, their campaign has already attracted , signatures – and counting.  The girls said: “We like to go to eat at Burger King and McDonald’s but ­children only play with the plastic toys they give us for a few minutes before they get thrown away and harm animals and pollute the sea.” Staggeringly, McDonald’s is the largest toy distributor in the world, handing out more than . billion a year in a tsunami of single-use plastic.
