story: The charity is encouraging Scots to apply for the benefits they are entitled to, as it found % of those polled ran out of cash at least once in the last year.More than a thirdof these people said they had gone without food for their household.The research, which involved  workers being questioned by YouGov earlier this year, was published ahead of an expected announcement from the Scottish Government on an income supplement later this week.CAS chief executive Derek Mitchell said: "We are seeing too many people really struggling, even people in work."The research data we publish today exposes the extent of the problem."This is an unacceptable situation and it is clear that serious solutions are required."He added: "We hope to see progress on the income supplement this coming week as well as the right to food being enshrined in Scots law through the Good Food Nation Bill this parliament."In the meantime, we can ensure people are getting the social security payments they are entitled to as well as checkthey could be paying lower bills for utilities and council tax."The vast majority of people in Scotland support the principles of our welfare state, that we all pay in and get support when we need it."Previous polling by YouGov for CAS suggested more than % of Scots believe those in a job who have to claim benefits work hard but their wages are not enough to cover living costs.

title: ossian-and-scotland-part-our-own-history-which-at-long-last-we-can-stop-being-embarrassed-about
story: By Phil MillerTHEY were Scottish stories which transfixed the western world, a literary sensation telling tales of an epic, misty heroic past that became one of the greatest controversies of their age.The Ossian tales, published by schoolmaster James Macpherson in the s, were bestsellers, and gripped European culture in a way few stories from Scotland have done before of since.But after years of controversy, is it time for Scotland to stop being defensive about Ossian In their time, Macphersonrsquos works were a sensation. Napoleon slept, it is said, with a version of the ldquoCeltic Homer under his pillow as he fought his campaigns in Egypt, and the German literary giant Goethe was famously inspired by the tales of the blind, third-century bard Ossian, and the adventures of Fingal and Oscar, Malvina and King Swaran.Indeed, Macphersonrsquos writings ndash fragments, he contended, of ancient Gaelic stories, tales and songs that he had collected, translated and heard ndash inspired composers, poets, politicians and artists across Europe. In Britain alone, the works of the man from Ruthven, Badenoch, influenced Burns and Blake, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Scott and Byron.However, the Ossian tales as told by Macpherson in a series of publications starting with Fragments Of Ancient Poetry in  ndash largely gloomy stories of wars and loss, tumultuous epic landscapes roiling with storms and conflict ndash were publicly savaged by critics, most notably Samuel Johnson, one of the most famous men of letters of his day.Johnson said the Ossian tales as presented by Macpherson were ldquoas gross an imposition ever the world was troubled with. The charge was that Macpherson was a fraud, and had essentially written the works himself.The controversy was huge at the time: Macpherson defended his work,not as robustly as an author may do in these more media-savvy times ndash one account notes that he challenged Johnson to a duel ndash and the Highland Society of Scotland launched an official investigation, which found, albeit not until , that he had used genuine material in his work.Some  years later, Macphersonrsquos works are little known, and have not benefited from a renaissance in their audience through radio, television or film: Ossian is not a namethat creates many ripples in popular culture.However, a major new show at Scotlandrsquos National Museum ndash Wild and Majestic: Romantic Visions of Scotland, which opens this week ndash hopes to shine a new light on the Ossian controversy. It shows the Ossian tales as crucial to the development of Romantic thought and literature in the late th century, and states clearly, and provides evidence, that Macpherson based his work on authentic texts.Scholars, too, see the whole controversy at the crux of a tension between industrialised central Scotland and the rapidly changing Highlands, and between Scottish culture and the burgeoning idea of British Empire and the dominance of obviously ldquoEnglish culture.Johnsonrsquos ridiculing of Macpherson was much more than a literary argument: the cultural and political undercurrents of the controversy are unmistakable.The exhibition includes one of Macphersonrsquos sources, the Red Book of Clanranald. It adds: ldquoJames Macpherson maintained that his translations of the Ossian cycle were based on authentic Gaelic verse, ballads and songs, collected during his travels in the Scottish Highlands ... Macpherson consulted and collected original Gaelic manuscripts belonging to numerous Highland families.ldquoThese included the Red Book of Clanranald, a volume containing the history and lore of Clan Donald, which was compiled by a member of the MacMhuirich family of bards.The curator of the show, Dr Patrick Watt, said that Macpherson was ldquoscholarly and rigorous in his research.He said: ldquoMacpherson definitely made use of old manuscript sources, we have that one in our show. Itrsquos very interesting to see how he approached his task ndash he had evidence. These are real things, whether he actually changed them or not, we are almost past that now.ldquoI think when you look at it for what it is ndash a lasting interpretation of the remnants of Gaelic poetry ndash then it is fantastic. If you read them, they are incredibly interesting, the characters that are portrayed are fascinating ... the thing that really hit me was that you have a man who goes for himself to investigate these documents. Why did he do this  I doubt it was because he thought it was going to be a best seller.One of the contributors to the show, Dr Domhnall Uilleam Stiugravebhart of Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, believes it is high time for Scotland to move beyond the debate over the ldquoauthenticity of Macphersonrsquos Ossian tales.He said: ldquoYou could talk about it for hours, it is an under-researched part of our own history, which at long last, we can stop being embarrassed about. Put to one side questions of authenticity, and think about how it was put together. It was not just a work of literature, it was seen as a historical document when it was first being produced. It was first produced with footnotes.ldquoMacpherson ushered in an age of romantic nationalism which is still with us. We have never really left that age, and by looking at Macpherson we can fruitfully compare him with other national myths, national epics that were being created, or shall we say recreated, in the th and th centuries, including JRR Tolkienrsquos own attempts to provide the English with national myth in the form of Lord of the Rings.Of the controversy, he added: ldquoIs Macpherson a fraud and a faker ndash or is he perhaps trying to do something possibly a bit more interesting with his own native culture  There is absolutely no doubt, first of all, that he made stuff up.ldquoAt the same time, and we should say that very quickly indeed, he was drawing upon an existing culture of Gaelic, heroic ballads common to both Scotland and Ireland, they date from the middle ages, and they are about Fionn mac Cumhaill and his heroic band, and the defender of Ulster, Cuacutechulainn.Professor Nigel Leask, Regius Chair of English language and literature at the University of Glasgow, says that scholarship suggests Macpherson drew upon about  traditional Fenian ballads ndash that is, medieval and post-medieval heroic ballads in Gaelic relating the feats of Fionn mac Cumhaill and his warrior band the Fianna ndash working from notes of transcriptions made from oral performances and some old Gaelic manuscripts.He added: ldquoBut there was a lot of lsquopaddingrsquo, and his most ambitious long poems Fingal and Temora presented the ballads in the form of epics, modelled on the th centuryrsquos understanding of Homerrsquos Iliad and modern sentimental poetry.Professor Tom Devine, the distinguished historian, has another view of the Macpherson controversy. He notes the tension between the myth that Macpherson was writing, and the reality of Scotland ndash and indeed Britain ndash in the late th century.The stormy epic, godless but noble and ancient, contrasted with a country rapidly gearing up to the Industrial Revolution and, in the Highlands, the Clearances.Devine said: ldquoThe impact of Ossian in Europe was quite extraordinary. Itrsquos dficult now, in the cold light of the st-century day, to think of how the celebrati in Europe were seduced by him. The other aspect is you are dealing with two parallel universes at this time ndash at the same time as this almost fictionalised Highland Scotland was being projected, the break-up of the real traditional society was accelerating rapidly.ldquoOssian was having an impact from the s. And that is the decade when you are beginning to see the rapid commercialisation of Highland society. The s are a real break point in the journey towards modernity in Scotland ... we see the first signs of emigration on a major scale, and the first removals from land at a signicant level. So at the same time as a romanticisation is going on, a quite dferent narrative is occurring at the same time.Devine added that the way Macpherson wrote in the tales suggested ndash sometimes explicitly ndash that Highlanders of the late th century were ldquothe antique past, living in the present, in a way which did not exist anywhere  in Britain, a seductive idea because of the ldquosheer pace of advancing modernity in the UK.The works, too, Leask notes, ldquogave new dignity to Gaelic culture and language that had been crushed in the aftermath of Culloden [in ] and, in a way still seen in modern marketing images for Scottish tourism, ldquocast a romantic light on the rugged mountain landscape, and even turned terrible weather ndash mist and rain ndash into a sublime Ossianic experience, encouraging huge number of tourists to visit the region in the romantic period.Watt notes that the debate over Macpherson and what was authentic and what was his own invention may carry on for many years yet.Stiugravebhart added: ldquoYou can spend your entire time knocking your head against a wall, playing lsquospot the genuine versersquo in Ossian. I am not saying we should move on from that, but I think a more fruitful line of enquiry would be to try to examine and analyse what Macpherson was up to, and beyond that, why at this particular juncture this should be such an attractive literary production, not just for people in Scotland but across the world.ldquoI think the first thing to say about Macpherson is that he didnrsquot work alone. He was the poster boy of a coterie of Scottish enlightenment figures who were interested in Scotlandrsquos past and what that past might tell us about the development of society. So, OK, he was creating literature, but he was also bringing to light these incredibly valuable documents, which illustrated what le might have been like in Scotland, , years before.Macpherson, who died in , perhaps did not help himself.Leask says his original inspiration was existing traditional Scottish and Irish ballads about Fionn mac Cumhaill with which he had been familiar since boyhood in the ceilidh houses of Badenoch, as well as further material he collected in the Highlands and Islands in -.He added: ldquo[The verses] were only lsquoauthenticrsquo in the sense that he had freely adapted traditional Gaelic Fenian poetry ndash it would have been betterhe had admitted as much. He was a dficult and curmudgeonly personality, but made a lot of money from his successful literary career.The Ossian texts are available in current publishing such as Blind Ossianrsquos Fingal, published by Luath Press of Edinburgh.Watt says thata filmmaker adapted the works for the screen, the current general lack of knowledge of Macphersonrsquos works would quickly be overturned. In the meantime, the texts are still available to read ndash Leask says itrsquos best to ldquotry reading it loud, taking long breaths, to capture the flavour of the original.Stiugravebhart added, of reading the often ldquogloomy and morbid works: ldquoYoursquove got to let yourself go, plunge in, and live in the moment. Someit is unreadable, some it isnrsquot. Some of it echoes or gives a foretaste of what other romantic writers, with better reputations, would write over the next two generations.ldquoItrsquos always worth having a go with Ossian, and see what you think.Wild and Majestic: Romantic Visions of Scotland, National Museum of Scotland, Edinburgh, runs from June  until November .

title: headline-to-come
story: WHEN she talks about her fatherrsquos long and tortured last days her voice begins to crack. It is only when she gets on to who she blames for killing him and failing her and her family that it regains a steely edge.Justine Gordon-Smith holds the Scottish and UK Governments responsible. For their failure, not just to properly compensate for infecting their dad with the blood products which would finally kill him, but virtually abandoning him and his complex needs and leaving her and her sister to provide round-the-clock care as he became more and more ill.Justine is one of four girls, two of her sisters live away, so it was left to her and her sister Rto look after their father Peter in Edinburgh as he deteriorated from a caring and funny man to a bedridden one they could barely recognise. All four were at his bedside when he died and she can be precise about it ndash it was .pm on July , just  days, she notes, after the Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service, which infected him, opened its ldquoshiny new pound million building in the Heriot Watt Centre.Peter Gordon-Smith was a well-known figure on the Scottish music and entertainment scene, a musician and primarily double bass player ndash he backed Shirley Bassey and others ndash and he managed night clubs, worked at the Citizensrsquo Theatre in Glasgow under the legendary Iain Cuthbertson, even managed a youth hostel in the Edinburgh.ldquoHe was a very outgoing man. He loved a yarn and a funny story. He could charm anyone, she recalls. ldquoHe was a very talented musician and he was also very handsome.Peter was a haemophiliac. ldquoWhen we were young I remember him having the odd bleed and he would go to hospital for a few days. But it was manageable. ldquoYou were always very conscious of it and how an injury would affect him.It was in  that Peter was told he was infected with the Hepatitis C virus, although he was not told how he got it or when. It is clear, however, from his medical records that he received clotting agents Factor VIII and cryoprecipitate produced by the transfusion services Protein Fractionation Centre and administered by the Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh, the RIE.ldquoHe was absolutely outraged when he was told. There was a distinct lack of information about how he became infected. Dad looked into suing the hospital, but that didnrsquot go ahead.Justine, like all the core participants in the new inquiry, has had to sign a non-disclosure agreement ndash in case information at this stage might prejudice future legal chargesanyone is held responsible ndash but she is determined not to be completely silenced.For  years, from when he was told about the infection which would finally kill him, the family received no help or compensation. In  the UK Government set up and funded three charities ndash while refusing to admit liability ndash one of which was the Skipton Fund.ldquoAround that time R found out about it in a newspaper article and we applied to Skipton. Peter subsequently received pound, as well as pound a quarter. The money was used to do up his house, just a stones throw from the Scottish Parliament.Justine, a filmmaker, who was brought up in Edinburgh with sister R, had been living in London but in  ed to pursue a doctorate at Edinburgh University in film and geography. She and R were shortly to become their dadrsquos full-time carers.ldquoHe had been badly beaten in the  and spent a long time in the RIE in . He developed what they call an inhibitor - the clotting agents were facing increasing resistance - and he would turn over in bed and bleed, or opening the door, even shaking hands.In  he developed sores in his legs which refused to heal. In that same year he had a fall in the bath, which led to him developing even more resistance to clotting. At the beginning of  Justine asked the hospital to perform a liver test on Peter. It revealed cancer.ldquoWe used to call him the Comeback Kid, he was so stoic, but this time he said lsquoIrsquove finally hit the buffersrsquo, she recalled.Skipton awarded Peter a further pound,.In May  he was told the cancer was terminal and there would be no further treatment. He was put on steroids and other drugs. ldquoUp until he took the steroids he was a lovely dad. As soon as he took them he went.Justine and her R were now alternating carers. She says she was repeatedly told she was ineligible for carers allowance because she was a student and was unable to work. Later, the sisters were given  hours a week assistance.Peter tried to kill himself in July, taking a massive overdose. After an alert, because the part-time carer couldnrsquot get in, Justine rushed to the house. Her father was saved.ldquoHe was put on fentanyl [a powerful opioid]. This strange creature then appeared who was not our dad, Justine recalls.There was a second suicide attempt in September ndash ldquoGod knows how many Tramadol he took ndash and again he was brought out of it.ldquoThat was the only time I saw him as my dad again. He was so angry he wasnrsquot dead. He didnrsquot want to be alive.Justine and R installed a drug safe in the house so he couldnt try that method again, but he was later to attempt it a third time by stabbing himself. She adds, on the verge of tears again, ldquoWe had become his jailers and his prisoners.After the sisters had taken turns on seven-nights-a-week suicide watch without any support they were given a carer for three nights.ldquoEventually we got seven nights a week, but only when Dad was so frail he required double staffing, but we got at least to sleep in our own beds, Justine says.In  the Scottish Government set up the Scottish Infected Blood Support Scheme which replaced the Skipton and other charities. While it makes payments to those infected, and to partners and dependent children, non-dependent children, carers like Justine and R, donrsquot qualy.ldquoHow can you say itrsquos generous  Why doesnrsquot the government just hold up its hand like the Republic of Ireland The Irish Government has paid out over euro billion in compensation, with the average award euro,.ldquoMy sister lost twenty-one thousand pounds from not working and Irsquom about seventy thousand out of pocket, she says.But itrsquos not about money, itrsquos about justice. ldquoI am outraged at the way our father, our family and other victims and their families have been treated. I hear of cases on a daily basis that makes my soul weep. Families who have had to spend  years fighting for basic health care and benefits for children whose health and lives have been destroyed because of HIV or Hepatitis C infection from blood products.ldquoPeople are dying yesterday, today and tomorrow.

title: botanic-garden-plan-for-the-rockefeller-centre-to-celebrate-scottish-links
story: Botanic garden plan for the Rockefeller Centre to celebrate Scottish linksRockefeller Center HolidaysThe Rockefeller Centre graces the Manhattan skyline, one of New York Cityrsquos many landmarks and famous for its cluster of towering Art Deco buildings, the buzz of Radio City and twinkling Christmas ice rink.Stretching to  acres and consisting of more than a dozen sky-high buildings, the urban expanse is home to art and culture, retail and restaurants, commerce and entertainment.With its soaring stone buildings, bronze gilded Prometheus statue overlooking skaters on the ice and countless tourists, there is little elbow room for grass, trees and flowers to thrive unless on one of the many roof gardens.Yet later this year the famous Rockefeller Centre will celebrate the legacy and le of a remarkable doctor and botanist, whose Scottish roots led to the creation of Americarsquos first public botanic garden on its very site.In August, the bustle of Midtown Manhattan will pause to reflect on a long-gone age when the streets, pavements and skyscrapers around them were a lush oasis of thousands of carefully cultivated native plants and meadows inspired by Scotlandrsquos own Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh.Recognition of the major role Elgin merchantrsquos son Dr David Hosack played in establishing the cityrsquos remarkable early th-century botanic garden and a wealth of institutions which brought together its brilliant minds, has seen a stretch of formal gardens within the famous Rockefeller Centre planted in his honour.The sqft Channel Gardens, a line of display gardens and water features in the centre of the ft plaza promenade, have been replanted with native plants, many no longer found growing naturally within the city, and the likes of which Hosack once featured in his sprawling Elgin Botanic Garden.The Channel Gardens setting will also provide the backdrop to an event on August , when groups will gather to mark the th anniversary of Hosackrsquos birth.The celebrations coincide with revived interest in the remarkable le of a figure who was celebrated by Americans in his letime but later faded into obscurity only to be revived partly thanks to blockbuster Broadway musical, Hamilton.Hosack appears in the hit show in his real-le role of physician to both American founding father Alexander Hamilton and his foe, Aaron Burr, during their fateful duel.But his transformation of what was once a rolling landscape of oak trees and wildflowers ndash and which by the th century would become a symbol of urban development and wealth ndash was rooted in his Scottish heritage.Author Victoria Johnson, who explores Hosackrsquos le in her  Pulitzer Prize-nominated book American Eden, said his passion was inspired by a trip to Edinburgh.ldquoWhen he finished his studies in New York and Philadelphia, he decided to go to the best medical education in the world which was at Edinburgh Universityrsquos medical faculty.ldquoHis father was born in Elgin and had settled in New York. He was interested in seeing where his father had come from.Having arrived in Edinburgh, his eyes were opened by the breadth of knowledge of botany that thrived in the city.Johnson adds: ldquoHe wrote lsquoI am very much mortied by my ignorance of botanyrsquo. He was surrounded by people who were completely conversant in botanical science and he didnrsquot know a thing.Hosack resolved to improve his knowledge, and spent hours in botany classes and exploring Edinburghrsquos gardens, including the original botanic garden in Edinburghrsquos Leith Walk, which later evolved into todayrsquos Royal Edinburgh Botanic Garden.Back in New York, he ventured beyond the city limits to Manhattanrsquos untamed pastoral landscape where in  he paid under , for a -acre stretch of land. There he built greenhouses inspired by the ones hersquod seen in Edinburgh and paid tribute to his fatherrsquos birthplace by naming it Elgin Botanic Garden.ldquoHe planted all kinds of agricultural crops, adds Johnson. ldquoItrsquos amazing to think he was growing barley, wheat, cotton and sunflowers on land where the Rockefeller Centre stands today.ldquoHe experimented with native and non-native species. He taught students how to identy plants and prepare medicines, and they conducted chemical experiments to figure out whether plants that were not known could have medical properties.ldquoHe built two ft conservatories which were clearly modelled on the ones hersquod seen in Leith Walk and had plants brought from all over the world.The conservatories faced what is now Fth Avenue, while streets which today are a hub for commerce and retail were surrounded by a belt of forest trees and shrubs. Exotic flowers, plants and fruits, which had never before been seen by New Yorkers, thrived within the garden walls.His visit to Edinburgh and London had also inspired him to gather the cityrsquos brightest minds to lay the foundations for organisations that moulded the cityrsquos future.ldquoHe saw his city through new eyes, she says.ldquoIt was a small town of , at the time, there were pigs walking through the streets and no major institutions.However, having spent over  million in todayrsquos money funding his garden, Hosackrsquos wealth was running dry. It was first passed to the State of New York and then to Columbia College.Hosack died in , just a week after losing tens of thousands of pounds in the Great Fire of New York.Meanwhile, his precious garden fell into ruin, the plants were ripped up, roads became overgrown and the glasshouses were destroyed.Eventually, the college leased the land to John D Rockefeller Jnr to become the lavish Rockefeller Centre.Johnson said the celebrations marking the anniversary of his birth brought his achievements full circle.ldquoHe was an amazing man and I am delighted that the Rockefeller Centre is now celebrating the legacy of the land on which it sits.American Eden by Victoria Johnson is published by WW Norton

title: scottish-government-accused-of-pandering-to-bigots-over-gra-delays
story: The First Minister has also come under fire, described as losing control of her party after a heated debated erupted over the GRA plans in the past year.Equalities secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville this week announced the Scottish Government would carry out a second consultation on the proposals, which would see transgender people allowed to self-declare their gender and make it easier for them to obtain a gender recognition certicate.Somerville also announced that the age of gender recognition would remain at , and there would be no extension of legal gender recognition to non-binary people.A -week consultation was already held in , with more than , people responding. More than % of respondents supported the plans.The plans have been at the centre of controversy after some womens groups, backed by several prominent SNP MSPs and MPs, say the new legislation could put womens spaces at risk.They claim that predatory men could access womens refuges, toilets and other facilities.Now transgender and non-binary Scots have spoken out about their disappointment following Sommervilles announcement on Thursday.Emily Frood, a trans woman from Edinburgh, said: "Irsquom ashamed, disappointed, and incredibly upset by the actions the Scottish Government have taken this week in relation the GRA reform."Trans and non-binary people in Scotland have been let down."The Scottish Government has suggested reforming the GRA in a frankly half-arsed capacity. I would rather a broken manesto promise of not getting the reform implemented by , than have a pathetic reform that includes a not fully self-declaratory method, fails to include  and  year olds as eligible, and completely ignores the validation and recognition of non-binary genders."Theyrsquore pandering to a vocal minority of ill-informed and bigoted iniduals, many from the within the SNP, who suggest that the rights of trans people have a detrimental effect on the rights of women. This has never been the case."Irsquove campaigned on this reform for nearly four years and to see it get ripped to shreds as a result of what comes across as a public pressure from a minority of bigoted people is heartbreaking.Kerry Rush, who is non-binary and from Edinburgh, added: "To say Irsquom disappointed is an understatement. Irsquom heartbroken, for myself and for the entire trans and non-binary communities. We waited  months to hear from the Scottish government about our rights, or lack thereof. We were led to believe they were working to help usbe legally recognised and instead we received two pitul sentences [In Sommervilles statement]."Non-binary people are people and deserve to live and love as part of wider society with the same rights and privileges as others. Instead what this so called progressive Scottish government has done is send a message of absolute disrespect and disregard for all non-binary people."I exist and I wonrsquot be erased. I will keep fighting for my existence to be recognised."One senior SNP source said that the decision to roll back on the manesto pledge is down to "weak leadership, and the First Minister not having enough control at the top."Colin Macfarlane, director at Stonewall Scotland said: "Now that the government has made this announcement, and it has fallen well short of what we had hoped, they are going to have to show leadership to ensure they tackle transphobic language when they hear it and when they see it, and ensure it is called out. "Trans people have had their lives put under the microscope now for the past  months, so it is the governmentrsquos duty of care now to ensure that that rhetoric is dialled down while we go through yet another consultation."Cabinet Secretary for Equalities Shirley-Anne Somerville said: ldquoWe know that some in the trans community will be feeling a sense of deep disappointment at what they see as a lack of progress on trans rights. I want to reassure them that the Scottish Government is committed to reforming the  Act and to removing unnecessary barriers for trans people to live in their true gender. We are committed to doing so during the current parliamentary session.ldquoHowever, it is important for that reform to be passed with strong support from across the Chamber and wider society. So we want to move forward but we also want to achieve consensus where possible.ldquoThe debate about the rights of transgender people is becoming very polarised and we all have a part to play in reducing tensions and encouraging respectful debate. Everyone has a responsibility to unite against transphobia, just as we do against homophobia and any other form of prejudice and discrimination.

title: how-toy-story-revolutionised-animation
story: The studiorsquos st feature- film, Toy Story , was released two days ago, and though manynot most reviews were highly positive, some critics thought the series had come to a fitting end with its predecessor, Toy Story .ldquoWoody and Co will have you sobbing like a baby, ran the headline in one review in a national newspaper last week, the reviewer being hugely impressed with the filmrsquos emotional impact and with the ldquothought and care that Pixar was ldquostill prepared to lavish on [its] crown-jewel franchise.ldquoSame fun, same charm ndash but now we need to let go, was the headline above another review, the critic noting that while the film is ldquosprightly, sweet-natured and gorgeous to look at it was ldquofundamentally repeating itself.It seems all but certain, however, that Toy Story , which propels Woody, Buzz and the rest of the toys headlong into a new adventure, will become Pixar Animation Studiosrsquo fourth  billion-grossing film.When the first Toy Story made its bow, back in , it was immediately seen as a great leap forward in animation ndash the worldrsquos first computer animated feature film.It was "a monumental landmark in animation history", writes Stephen Cavalier in his authoritative guide, The World History Of Animation. "It is the seismic moment when [director] John Lasseter and Pixar proved to the world that it was possible to make fully-developed, sympathetic characters with human personalities through computer animation."Toy Story was a box-office smash, an instant classic, and a film that took its audience ndash adults and children alike ndash seriously. It was nominated for three Oscars, with Lasseter himself being presented with a Special Achievement Academy Award.ldquoSuddenly, writes Cavalier, ldquothe rush was on for computer-animated features.The rush became a torrent, with ious Hollywood animation studios getting in on an increasingly lucrative trend in film-making and opening a new chapter in the history of animation, a history in which key moments had ranged from early Disney classics to works by influential figures as erse as Tex Avery, Ray Harryhausen and Stirling-born Norman McLaren.Today, the list of top-earning animation movies on the Box Office Mojo website is headed by such films as Incredibles  , Finding Dory, Shrek , The Lion King, Toy Story , Frozen, Finding Nemo, The Secret Le Of Pets, Despicable Me , and Inside Out. Merchandising tie-ins and DVD sales have also been hugely profitable.In , the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences launched a new Oscar category, for Animated Feature Film. The first winner was DreamWorks Animationrsquos Shrek, followed in successive yea rs by Spirited Away, Finding Nemo, The Incredibles, Wallace  Gromit in The Curse Of The Were-Rabbit, Happy Feet, Ratatouille, WALL-E, Up, Toy Story , Rango, Brave, Frozen, Big Hero , Inside Out, Zootopia, Coco, and Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse. Of these  winners, no fewer than half were products of Disney Pixar.Animated films have become increasingly sophisticated in terms of their storylines. Again, Disney Pixar has blazed an adventurous trail, giving the world films about a lonely little robot cleaning up a ruined Earthan elderly widower who tethers balloons to his house in order to embark on one last adventurethe control centre of the mind of an -year-old girland a young Mexican boy stranded in the Land of the Dead .There was also that remarkably daring scene in Toy Story  when for a few minutes the toys resigned themselves to be an appalling fate, in a trash-incinerating facility. This, observed Empire film magazine, was ldquoa scene of such intense, exquisite end-of-the-line poignancy mdash also the scariest moment of the whole [Toy Story] series mdash that it deserves comparison with Snow Whitersquos terried forest flight, or the shooting of Bambirsquos mother.Indeed, much has been made of the emotional palette of the best animated films, and of the "le lessons" that can be learned from them. "Negative feelings are perfectly okay" is one such, gleaned from Inside Out. Bereavement and grief were powerful impulses in Up.The software used in the making of the films has steadily grown more sophisticated, too.Asnoted this week, the first Toy Story film, in addition to being a critical and box-office success, also helped Pixar to win an ldquoanimation arms race, with visual effects going on to become a staple of blockbuster films. The crucial weapon in all of this, the paper added, is RenderMan, a software tool that enables film-makers to create photorealistic computer images.Toy Story  was made on an updated version of RenderMan, using ray tracing, which, says the , allows animators to achieve granular detail on light shading.Rob Redman, editor of D World  D Artist, is quoted as saying: ldquoThe outdoor scenes in Toy Story  are really where it comes into its own. You get the blues and greens where the sky is bouncing off the floor: it makes everything feel lush and vibrant. "Realistic" is not quite the word, but it does feel more real. The textures feel more believable.The Spectatorrsquos film critic, Jasper Rees, concurs. ldquoThe animation now has such a painterly exactness it may as well be real rain stubble tarmac up there on screen, he writes.And while Hollywood may dominate the world of animated movies itrsquos important to remember the influential work of, for example, Studio Ghibli, which is based in Tokyo.It has made a succession of strikingly beautul films, from Spirited Away and My Neighbour Totoro to Howlrsquos Moving Castle and Princess Mononoke.The Red Turtle, a superb animated fantasy ndash a French Japanese production "presented by Ghibli" ndash was described in the following terms by the prominent critic, Mark Kermode: ldquoA poignant, wordless tale of a man shipwrecked on a desert island, it boasts a sublime simplicity that unies its complex elements into a singular, universal voice."Eloquent, profound and moving, it left me with a heart full of bittersweet joy, a head dizzy with dreamy visions and cheeks wet from tears that rolled like waves on a distant beach.INCOMINGTHE big US studios have an impressive slate of animated films in the pipeline over the next few years. Some of them are sequels, taking the themes of the original hit film and exploring them further.Disneys Frozen , the long-awaited follow-up to s Frozen, the biggest-grossing animated musical of all time, will be in cinemas this winter.Pixar has two films due out next year: Onward , about two teenage elf brothers "who embark on an extraordinary quest to discoverthere is still a little magic left out there" and the newly-announced Soul, which will debut next June . The tagline reads: ldquoEver wonder where your passion, your dreams and your interests come from  What is it that makes you ... YOU DreamWorks Animation Studios, home to everything from Shrek to Madagascar and How To Train Your Dragon, has a list that includes Abominableand Trolls World Tour .The Box Office Mojo site lists several dozen animations that, sooner or later, will be in cinemas.

title: jeremy-hunt-preserving-the-union-comes-before-brexit
story: The Foreign Secretary, who is facing off against Boris Johnson to be the next Tory leader and Prime Minister, said he will support the Union ldquowith every drop of blood in his veins.It comes after a poll showed  per cent of Tory members would be happy to see Scotland split from the UK as the price of securing Brexit.Meanwhile, a separate survey for the Sunday Times found support for independence would surge to %Mr Johnson is handed the keys to Number .Asked about this, Mr Hunt said: ldquoThat poll shows why Irsquom the Prime Minister Nicola Sturgeon least wants, and for a very simple reason: that I believe in the union with every fibre of my being and I will never allow the union to be broken up as Prime Minister.ldquoAnd unlike Nicola Sturgeon, Irsquom on the side of the Scottish people who say they donrsquot want another isive referendum ndash they want the SNP Government to focus on health and education and things that matter to ordinary Scottish families, not things that ide them.The Foreign Secretary made the comments as he visited Peterhead in the north-east, where he met representatives of the fishing industry and later called in on his -year-old great-aunt Betty just outside Aberdeen.In a bid to woo Scottish Tory members ndash many of whom fear Mr Johnson could prove disastrous ndash Mr Hunt emphasised his Unionist credentials during his first trip north of the Border since the start of the race.However, he dodged questions about his rival Mr Johnsonrsquos private le, which has come under renewed scrutiny after police were called to his home following an apparent row with his girlfriend.Mr Hunt had earlier told Sky News that ldquosomeone who wants to be PM should answer questions on everything, but he would not be drawn further on the issue.AskedMr Johnson was fit to be Prime Minister, he told journalists in Peterhead: ldquoI think the trouble with criticising someone rsquos character is that we are all very aware of our own character flaws, and I think you go down a slippery path, and in the end itrsquos really bad for our political system.ldquoI think people should make their own judgements about the characters of the iniduals, but the debate I want to have,Irsquom going to criticise Boris for one thing, it is ducking every opportunity to debate properly on live TV what his solutions are to Brexit.ldquoThatrsquos the thing that matters most, and so Irsquom going to restrict my criticism to that because I think thatrsquos the thing that people most want to hear from our Prime Minister.International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, who supports Mr Hunt, signalled it would be betterMr Johnson was clear about what happened.He told BBCs The Andrew Marr Show: "I think it is always easier to just give an explanation."Mr Johnsons campaign for Number  was rocked by revelations police were called to the home he shares with his partner, Carrie Symonds, amid reports of shouting and banging. Yesterday, a poll suggested his popularity had been hit by the row.Mr Hunt, who spent part of his childhood in Scotland, said he did not believe the recent survey showing Tory members where in the UK would be prepared to ditch Scotland to deliver Brexit.He added: ldquoConservative Party members that I know are absolutely passionate about our precious Union.Asked how he would answer the question of what comes first, Brexit or the Union, he said: ldquoThe Union, every time.He also insisted Scots did not want another independence referendum.He said: ldquoI listen to the people of Scotland, and what theyrsquore saying is that they donrsquot want the isiveness that set friend against friend, family against family ndash they donrsquot want that.ldquoI think itrsquos time that Nicola Sturgeon did what the people of Scotland want, which is to focus on health and education and all the things that she was elected to deliver.Elsewhere, Mr Hunt said he was ldquohappy to look at plans to create a free port in Aberdeen or Peterhead, which would hand lucrative tax breaks to companies. Mr Johnsonrsquos team is reported to be advancing such a scheme.The Foreign Secretary also said it is important to have a ldquopro-business immigration policy and insisted he does not support slashing migration to the tens of thousands.He said he would be open to lowering the planned pound, salary threshold for EU workers in the face of criticism from senior Scottish Tories that this bar is too high for Scotland.

title: TV REVIEW  Did Downton Delhi leave you hot and bothered
story: WHAT on Earth did we ever do with our Sunday evenings before male actors tore off their shirts to reveal sculpted chests glistening with sweat The latest to selflessly exploit their own bodies in the name of light entertainment was Tom Bateman, star of Beecham House, ITVrsquos new drama.Not that he gave up his modesty easily. It was a whole  minutes before his character, John Beecham, joined the proud tradition fostered by Colin Firthrsquos Mr Darcy and Aidan Turnerrsquos Poldark. For a horribly long while it seemed asthe custom had died, but then balance was restored and viewers could relax into the tale of an eighteenth century English trader embarking on a new start in Delhi.Created by Gurinder Chadhaand Paul Mayeda Berges, Beecham House has been dubbed the Delhi Downton Abbey. At first sight, the two dramas have a lot in common. Set in palatial homes with gossipy servants, check. A host of strong women vying to rule the roost. Check. Elephants hellip. Er, wersquoll let Beecham House have that one.: This isnt Downton Abbey - no offenceEvery now and then an elephant trumpeted its presence just to remind the viewer that they were not in Kansas, or Yorkshire, any more.The most exotic beast to be found in Downtonrsquos precincts was the awkwardly named Isis, the yellow Labrador. In Beecham House everything was lavish, sumptuous, and larger than le, including a few of the performances.We met Beecham as he stumbled on a robbery and saved a rich manrsquos le. Cut to three years later and the Englishman was arriving at his new home in Delhi, a pile that made Downton look like a single end in Dennistoun. Clearly, he had been busy making money those few years. Perhaps he invented a powder that eased the symptoms of colds and flu.But wait. There was talk of him being a former soldier and working for the giant East India Company. That was all behind him, Beecham assured a suspicious emperor. He was not in the business of stealing business from anyone. All he wanted to do now, he swore, was trade fairly and live peaceably in this beautul country.There did not seem much chance of that happening. A conniving Frenchman, General Castillonwanted Beecham off his patch. Beechamrsquos mother arrived in town, with a young woman in tow that she reckoned would make a perfect we for her son. Plus, there was a baby in the house that announced itself as often as the elephant. Said baby was ldquonot fully European, as one of the servants put it. A little more should be revealed in the second of six instalments, showing tonight.: Damien Loves pick of the weekNo wonder Beecham, in a bid to relieve his tension, whipped off his shirt and hacked away at some innocent shrub.Bateman, last seen in another period drama, Vanity Fair, is often mentioned as a future Bond, alongside Scotlands Richard Madden and several others.There is one thing missing from Beecham House, something essentialit is to truly be the new Downton Abbey, and that is a sense of humour. Beechamrsquos mother, played in a nice twist by Lesley Nicol, aka Mrs Patmore in Downton, is nicely tetchy but she is no Maggie Smithrsquos Dowager Countess.Still, it is early doors and the mix of history, setting, and intrigue whispers potential. AndGeneral Castillon should feel the need to take off that stling unorm one night, who would blame him Continues tonight, ITV, pm

title: ridge-on-sunday-the-marr-show-sunday-politics-scotland-review
story: To Remainers v Leavers, Yes v No can now be added the Rod Stewart societyversus the Chas  Dave faction, who would be happy to rabbit on about the matter till the chlorinated chickens come home to roost.First up was Sir Ed Davey on Sky Newsrsquos Ridge on Sunday. The contender for the Liberal Democrat leadership was firmly in the Chas  Dave camp, saying Mr Johnson was not fit to be Prime Minister. He was followed by Labourrsquos Andrew Gwynne, Shadow Communities Secretary. Surprisingly, he said Labour would back a second referendum on Brexit. Unsurprisingly, he agreed on Mr Johnsonrsquos unsuitability for office.: Police called after altercationIt seemed like people wanted to give Mr Johnson a ldquokicking this morning, said host Sophy Ridge. Since her first question to almost every guest was about the former Foreign Secretary, this could have hardly come as a shock. Then again, how could she not ask  Ridge on Sunday may bill itself as ldquoa new type of politics show, whatever that means, as Prince Charles would say, but it could not ignore the story splashed over the weekend papers.Mr Johnson was the subject of the opening monologue on The Andrew Marr Show, with the Scot saying that before the news broke on Friday night about police being called to the Camberwell flat of Johnsonrsquos partner, Carrie Symonds, it had been assumed his journey to the leadership of his party and the UK was going to be a stroll in the park. ldquoWhether it is something or nothing, concluded Marr, ldquohe is not going to walk through this campaign.Marrrsquos final guest, after David Miliband on Iran US tensions and Labour MP Caroline Flint on a letter to Jeremy Corbyn demanding he rule out a second referendum, was Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary.: Preserving Union comes first says HuntA backer of Jeremy Hunt, surely he would take this chance to use the incident to attack Mr Johnson  Mr Fox is far too wily to do anything so obvious. While saying that private lives did not concern him, he also thought Mr Johnson should explain, as he had refused to do at hustings on Saturday, why police were called to the flat. ldquoI think it is always easier to just give an explanation, said the voice of sweet reasonableness. Mr Hunt wanted to have it both ways too, telling Sky News:"I think someone who wants to be PM should answer questions on everything, but Im not going to comment on character." Oh no, heaven forbid.Sunday Politics Scotland with Gordon Brewer had Scots Tory MP and Johnson backer Ross Thomson, live from Aberdeen. Speaking with a skew-whf photograph of the harbour behind him, Mr Thomson declared his membership of the Rod Stewart appreciation society. This was a personal matter for Boris, guv, not going to comment, letrsquos move on.Would you like a job in a Boris Johnson government, asked Brewer. ldquoIrsquom enjoying being on the back benches and I want to make Boris Johnson Prime Minister. Thatrsquos my job right now. That will be a big fat aye then.Struan Stevenson, former Conservative MEP, turned out to be a Rabbiter, saying the incident at the London flat had been ldquolike something out of EastEnders. Mr Stevenson was being interviewed in his garden as several little birds waged war noisily behind him. If you were looking for a metaphor for the current state of Conservative party politics it had just arrived, with bells and cheeps on.: How Johnson wonRidge on Sunday had a sit down with Nicola Sturgeon, which turned out to be both a good and a bad thing for the programme. The interview had been carried out in Edinburgh last Thursday, prior to the Johnson story breaking on Friday, so the First Minister could not be asked for her views on that. She did, however, say that his becoming leader would be disastrous for the Tories UK-wide but particularly in Scotland.Ridge askedshe felt sorry for Theresa May. ldquoErm hellip I hellip as someone in a leadership position I know how tough it is and I know how lonely it is so, yes on a human level I can have sympathy with the position she has been in. But it is also the case, and I donrsquot mean this in a nasty way, but she has in many respects brought the dficulties she encountered upon herself.The closing stages of any interview are always a tricky moment. If a sneaky question is coming, it will arrive then. Ridge had one for the FM, to wit: with Scotland now out of the FIFA Womenrsquos World Cup, who would she now be supporting Ah, the old ldquoAnyone But England question, the pit that Andy Murray once fell into at Wimbledon when England were in some tournament or other.: If Boris was PMldquoOh for goodness sake, laughed Ms Sturgeon, ldquogive me at least  hours. This is the day after the night before hellip I donrsquot know. Letrsquos see. I wish England well obviously I do, but asking a Scottish person the morning after wersquove been put out of a World Cup hellip just be a bit gentler on me than that please.Gentleness in politics  Asthat will ever catch on.

title: sir-vince-cable-claims-significant-numbers-of-labour-and-tory-mps-could-join-lib-dems
story: Vince Cable: Labour and Tory MPs could jump shipSir Vince CableandJeremy Corbyn during the commemorations for the tltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgth Anniversary of D-Dltspan classtruncate-full-screengtay in Portsmouth. But the Lib Dem leader says he could not work with Corbyn in a hung parliament. Pic: Andrew Matthews PA WireSir Vince said the brief prospect of a new centre party being formed was now dead and described Change UK as a media lsquobubblersquo.Speaking to Carolyn Quinn for the Westminster Hour on Radio , Sir Vince also rejected the idea of forming a post-election agreement with a Jeremy Corbyn led minority Labour Government.He said defections to the Lib Dems from both main parties were likely, adding: ldquoThere are quite a lot of Tory MPs, some Labour, who were going to make the jump and didnrsquot but are now realising that their position is becoming impossible who might well come to us. So wersquore talking to quite a wide group of people, not just the Independent MPs.But this raises a ldquobig question for his own party, he said. ldquohow we engage with the signicant number of Labour people and the Tory people who no longer belong in their parties. If they want to make a break, how do we do it Speaking about his own partyrsquos relative success in the European elections and the failure orf Change UK to win seats, he said: ldquoI donrsquot think we should be smug and go around saying, I told you so.ldquoBut they did make a serious miscalculation ndash and they were egged on by plenty of commentators who misunderstood what politics is all about. And people were playing around with these ideas about new parties ndash I think thatrsquos now dead.Change UK lacked party infrastructure, he said. ldquo It was just a media bubble and it burst.Askedthe Lib Dems could countenance a deal with a minority Labour government led by Jeremy Corbyn,the next election produces a hung Parliamentl, Sir Vince said: ldquoNo we couldnrsquot. Wersquore so far removed from him on Europe ndash where their commitment is to deliver Brexit and theyrsquore totally ambiguous on the referendum issue the fact that theyrsquove indulged anti-Semitism and some very unpleasant stuff in their own party and the economics is just fantasy. So therersquos no way we could contemplate a coalition [or] electoral deal with them.But he said he would be willing for the Lib Dems to cooperate with the Green Party with whom they agree on Brexit and climate change.

title: uk-envoys-bid-to-ease-tension-between-iran-and-us-stumbles
story: It leaves America and Iran still ldquoeyeball to eyeball, with relations between the two countries almost at boiling point.Foreign Office minister Andrew Murrison held talks with the Tehran government, calling for ldquourgent de-escalation and raised UK concerns ldquoabout Iranrsquos regional conduct and its threat to cease complying with the nuclear deal, according to a statement by the Foreign Office.The trip was announced after Donald Trump said the US was ldquococked and loaded to retaliate against Iran for downing an American drone on Thursday.The strikes were reportedly called off  minutes before they were to be carried out after Mr Trump was told  people could die.Dr Murrisonrsquos visit also came after the US accused Iran of attacking oil tankers earlier this month ndash which Iran denies.He said following talks: ldquoThis visit has provided an important opportunity for open, frank and constructive engagement with the Iranian Government. In Tehran I was clear about the UKrsquos long-held concerns over Iranrsquos activities in the region.ldquoI reiterated the UKrsquos assessment that Iran almost certainly bears responsibility for recent attacks on tankers in the Gulf of Oman. Such activity, which carries a high risk of miscalculation, needs to stop to allow for immediate de-escalation of rising tensions.ldquoAnd I was clear that the UK will continue to play its full part alongside international partners to find diplomatic solutions to reduce the current tensions.ldquoI reiterated the UKrsquos determination to maintain the nuclear deal which is in our shared security interests.But Kamal Kharazi, head of the Strategic Council of Foreign Relations at Iranrsquos Foreign Ministry, said Dr Murrison had only the ldquousual talking points.He said these included a European payment mechanism to help Iran with US sanctions and ldquothat Britain has always supported the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Actionbut he added that ldquosuch talks have always been repetitive.Britain is a signatory to the  nuclear deal which saw Iran scale back its nuclear programme in exchange for sanctions relief.Iranrsquos president accused the United States of fuelling the fire in an already volatile region.The official IRNA news agency quoted Hassan Rouhani as saying the ldquointerventionist military presence of the US is responsible for the Middle Eastrsquos problems.On Saturday, a spokesman for Iranrsquos armed forces warned that a military strike would ldquoset the region ablaze and burn up the US, its interests, and its allies.Mr Trump later tweeted that the US will impose ldquomajor additional sanctions on Iran after opting to halt military action ldquofrom going forward at this time.Former Foreign Secretary David Miliband said we are now in the midst of a ldquopressing global threat to peace and security.Mr Miliband told BBC Onersquos The Andrew Marr Show: ldquoThe current Foreign Secretary has real responsibilities at the moment. I donrsquot think we can afford him to be completely absent from the stage. Britain is a permanent member of the security council. This is a pressing global threat to peace and security.ldquoWersquore relying on the caution of President Trump to keep the hawks at bay in his own administration.Responding to what Mr Miliband said, Mr Hunt wrote on Twitter: ldquoAgree, and thankfully Irsquom not. Speaking regularly to my counterparts on this subject, including Sec Pompeo, have sent a minister to the region, and will be updating parliament on Tuesday. Extremely serious situation.Dr Murrisonrsquos visit amid the bellicose exchanges between Washington and Tehran is part of the UKrsquos ldquoongoing diplomatic dialogue with Iran, the Foreign and Commonwealth Officesaid.Mr Trump pulled out of a long-term deal struck with Iran in  to limit its sensitive nuclear activities and allow in international inspectors infor the lting of economic sanctions.The deal was signed by his predecessor Barack Obama along with the UK, France, China, Russia and Germany, which still support the agreement.But Mr Trump declared it a ldquoterrible deal and imposed more sanctions.On Saturday, German chancellor Angela Merkel called for a ldquopolitical solution on Iran, saying such a result ldquoshould not just be a hope, but it should be worked towards with the utmost seriousness.Tensions between the US and Iran have increased in recent weeks amid claims by Washington that Tehran has been behind attacks on oil tankers in the Persian Gulf.Dr Murrisonrsquos visit also took place amid continuing tension between London and Tehran over the treatment of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe, a British-Iranian dual citizen who has been detained in Iran since April  accused of spreading propaganda against Iran.Her husband Richard Ratclfe has been on a hunger strike outside the Iranian Embassy in London in support of his we who is also on hunger strike.Dr Murrison said he raised the issue, adding: ldquoWhile in Tehran, I also pressed again on behalf of the UK Government for the urgent and unconditional release of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe and all British-Iranian dual nationals who are being arbitrarily detained.Meanwhile, a top Iranian military commander warned yesterday that any conflict with Iran would have uncontrollable consequences across the region and endanger the lives of US forces.

title: andy-murray-roars-to-victory-in-queens-doubles
story: In a fairytale comeback, the sensational Scot triumphed in the Menrsquos Doubles final at Queenrsquos Club - and left the door open for a potentialto singles at the US Open in August.The -year-old had feared he may never play professionally again prior to having his hip resurfaced in January, but to roars from the crowd, he told them yesterday: ldquoMy hip felt great, there was no pain.Sir Andy and Spainrsquos Lopez beat Briton Joe Salisbury and American Rajeev Ram -- -.Lopez, , added the doubles to the singles title he won earlier in the day.Sir Andy, who had not won a doubles title since , said ending his comeback tournament with a win was ldquobrilliant.Prior to the Fever-Tree Championships, the two-time Wimbledon champion suggested he would keep faith with doubles until after the grand slam in New York, which starts at the end of August.But following a successful and, crucially, pain-free week in west London, Murray will have a rethink."If I keep progressing, I would like to try to play singles," he said."I think I have a couple of options after Wimbledon - either I continue with doubles but start training and practising singles through the US Open swing, and then try and maybe play singles after that."Or I take a longer break post-Wimbledon of maybe, lets say, a month or six weeks, to get myself ready for singles, and then try and play close to the US Open time."But I dont care really either way. It would be nice to play at the US Open butI dont - look, I got so much enjoyment and happiness after winning a first-round doubles match here that, you know, thats enough."It seemed at Queens that was not enough, though. The tennis ace, who was close to retiring in January as he was struggling to walk without pain, let alone play tennis, strolled off with the silverware at his first attempt back.Murray and Lopez - the latter fresh from winning the singles title less than an hour earlier - beat Britains Joe Salisbury and Rajeev Ram of the USA -- - after a third-set match tie-break.Murray had insisted after their first-round victory that winning was not his number one priority this week but the three-time grand slam champion has clearly not lost the appetite for a battle.The fledgling partnership was - down in a first-set tie-break but fought back to level, and took it when Ram pushed a forehand wide.The second set went the way of Salisbury and Ram after Murray dropped serve, and like so many matches during Murrays career, it went to the wire.Lopez, who must have been running on empty, somehow conjured up a series of stunning winners in the match tie-break to secure his own personal double and an unexpected, but welcome victory for Murray.He said:"Its incredible. Its tough to believe. I won this tournament in . That was the best win of my career. And then I did it again two years after, and then I won the doubles half an hour after that!."Murrays win lit up social media, with his mother, Judy, posting an image of the victors, saying: "Mothers pride."Martina Navratilova Tweeted: "How great to have @andy_murray back playing and congrats to him and also to @feliciano_lopez for winning both singles and double at #QueensTennis"

title: beef event one of the best yet
story: Early morning rain failed to deter farmers from attending the Scottish Beef Association#s Scotland#s Beef Event  held last month on a leading Aberdeenshire beef farm.Around , people streamed into North Bethelnie Farm, near Oldmeldrum, on Thursday, May .Rural Economy Cabinet Secretary, Fergus Ewing, speaking at the opening ceremony“It was a very successful day and generally recognised as one of the best of the biennial beef events the SBA has organised over the years,” said SBA vice-chairman, David Barron, who chaired the organising committee.“The  trade stands reported good business and the extensive technical demonstration area was thronged throughout the day with farmers keen to pick up all the latest technology for the beef industry.”Mr Barron was full of praise for the host farmers, Robbie and Barbara Milne, and their son, James, who put on a great show.One of the highlights of the day was the tour of the  acre all-grass farm – with no fewer than  tractors and trailers at the ready to avoid queuing – which took visitors right to the top of the hill, where they were treated to an ice-cream from neighbouring farmers, Mackie’s, while enjoying magnicent views of the Aberdeenshire countryside looking up to Bennachie.Beef farmers – like all farmers and indeed the whole of industry – are facing an uncertain future as the debacle and stalemate of the Brexit negotiations continues.The only thing farmers can do is to make sure they are operating as efficiently and productively as possible so they are in a strong position to cope with whatever hits them in the future – in or out of Europe – and they had plenty of pointers at the Beef Event which more than lived up to its theme - Breeding, Feeding, Succeeding.Rural Economy Cabinet Secretary, Fergus Ewing, who in giving the official opening address, reiterated his support for the beef industry and determination to reverse the continuing decline in the national beef herd.But saying is not doing although, in fairness to Mr Ewing, he dropped more than a broad hint that the Scottish Government is looking at an emergency support package for the beef sector. This could take the form of increased headage payments under the existing beef calf support scheme.The SBA, along with NFU Scotland and other industry stakeholders, have been pressing Mr Ewing on the issue and SBA chairman, Neil McCorkindale, was hoping for an announcement by the Cabinet Secretary at the event.This didn’t materialise but Mr Ewing indicated he was sympathetic to the plea and accepted the argument that headage payments would be a more effective approach than area based support which would simply encourage inertia in the industry.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Owners Jonny and Ali Aspden"  Popular Ellon coffee shop extends opening hoursviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aby Wilson, Stuart Wood, Elaine Lownds, George Laing, and Director Nicola Alexander of Bethan Customs Consultancy"  Oldmeldrum start-up doubles team viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: garioch sc launches new children s activities programme
story: Garioch Sports Centrethis week announced that it islaunching GSCkids, a new programme of children#s activities, in a bid to make children#s activities more accessible in the local area.Launching on Wednesday, August , children will still be able to enjoy their favourites, including additional football classes, and some new additions including Junior Boxercise.GSC will also be offering preschool gymnastics classes in partnership with Donside Gymnastics for the very first time.Sandra Simpson of Donside Gymnastics commented: “We’re delighted to be launching five brand new preschool gymnastics classes at Garioch Sports Centre. “Classes are suitable from .- years old and are the  perfect pathway into our school-age gymnastics programme.”Garioch Sports Centre’s Kevin Bonarius, chief operating officer, added: ‘The aim of GSCkids is to provide a safe and inclusive environment for local children and their families and carers to enjoy active lestyles while having fun.“Our doors are open to children of all ages and abilities. We invite them to come along, participate in sports, build their confidence and make friends.“We’ve designed GSCkids with busy families and accessibility in mind. We recognise that lots of parents and carers will be dropping off and picking up from school so we’ve avoided putting on classes at these times. “We want to give families the best possible chance to participate. With this in mind, we’ve also dropped the prices of lots of the classes we offer.“Lots of our preschool classes provide the ideal pathway into the next level of the chosen sport, should the children be keen. “There are routes for progression and competition but our main focus is always on having fun.“We’ve kept the favourites from the current timetable and added some new classes, including Junior Boxercise and Junior Gazelles, a junior running club that runs concurrently with our adults running club, Garioch Gazelles. “We’ve done this so that parents and carers can drop off their children at Junior Gazelles, then go and join the adults’ group at the same time. We’ve also launched FamilyFIIT – a fun fitness class suitable for kids from age eight – to encourage families to enjoy active lestyles together. data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Ross Whittingham, chief executive officer of Flowline Specialists"  Firm drives forward with new CEOviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Golfers at the CLAN fundraiser"  Newcomers swing to win thousands for CLAN Cancer Support at golf day viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“Initially, we’re adding three FamilyFIIT classes including one on a Saturday morning, but we will certainly look to add morethey prove popular.“Check out our websiteor app for timetables and class information.”

title: hotel welcomes chef ahead of renovation
story: A Newmachar hotel has appointed a prestigious new head chef as it prepares for a major renovation.Graham Mitchell, who has worked at top class venues including Aberdeen’s Moonfish Café, The Chester Hotel and Trump International has joined the Newmachar Hotel to prepare for a transformation of the popular bar and restaurant.Linda and Grant Wright, who have owned the hotel for over  years, are about renovate the eating areas of the hotel with the introduction of ‘The Scullery’.Graham is one of nine members of the Scottish Culinary team and will be taking part in the Culinary Olympics in February in Stuttgart, Germany, where  national teams will compete to win the coveted Olympic Champion title.The Newmachar Hotel recently won a host of awards at the North East of Scotland Hospitality Training Awards, including Graham being named best Scotch Beef Chef of the Year, runner-up Seafood Chef of the Year and the hotel was named winner for Bar Food Restaurant as well as Best Afternoon Tea Venue.”Graham joined the Newmachar Hotel in March, and he is looking forward to the renovations which are due later this year. He said: “As soon as I met Grant and Linda, I knew their ambition and vision matched my own. The plans they have are really exciting and I am looking forward to producing a brand new menu which will add a modern, clean twist to traditional Scottish country pub food.”The Newmachar Hotel’s popular restaurant will have a new look, a new welcome and a new menu.Linda Wright added: “We are very excited that Graham has joined the team, as we have watched his success for many years.“The Scullery will be for everyone, families, young and old, couples and friends just looking for a blether. We are teaming up with award-winning architects to bring the ultimate in modern style, whilst retaining our warm ambience, with sociable booths for larger and smaller parties.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Traffic wardens were scrapped by Aberdeenshire Council several years ago"  Traffic wardens couldunder fresh enforcement viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: scoop up books to win ice cream prize
story: The  Aberdeenshire Summer Reading Challenge was launched today at Inverurie Library.Last year, just over , children signed up for the challenge, which is organised by the library staff within Live Le Aberdeenshire. It encourages youngsters to read during the summer holidays, with a creative competition running alongside. Author Vivian French encouraged the children and adults in attendance to take part in the challenge. Each child taking part receives a collector card to keep track of the books they have read, collecting a sticker for each one and receiving a book prize after reading six books or more. The children will have the opportunity to do the challenge up to three times with other prizes being availablethey do it a second or third time.A book gt card will be awarded to the “Star Reader” from each library in Aberdeenshire. The lucky child will be chosen by library staff who have shown the most progress with their reading during the challenge.This year, the library service is going to award one of these children the title of “Aberdeenshire Star Reader” and the winner will be awarded a prize kindly donated by Mackie’s of Scotland - £ Book Gt Card and a year’s supply of Mackie’s Ice Cream.For this year’s creative competition, children are invited to design a bookmark with the theme of the love of reading. Prizes for the creative competition will be awarded to four age group categories – Pre-School, P to P, P to P  S+. Bookmarks will be submitted from each branch library with the four designs chosen from these entries being printed and distributed across Aberdeenshire.All Star Readers and Creative Competition overall winners will be invited to a special prize giving event taking place on Saturday, September  at Woodhill House in Aberdeen.Cllr Anne Stirling, Aberdeenshire Council’s Communities Committee chair, said: “Completing this challenge is a great achievement for young readers, and the benefits of that will last far beyond the summer.”Karin Hayhow, Marketing Director of Mackie’s of Scotland, added: “With making ice cream we are already committed to making the most of summer - and one excellent way to do that is to enjoy reading books. We love the Summer Reading Challenge idea and are pleased to be able to play our part in encouraging local children to enjoy as many books as possible over the summer holidays.”The challenge will run until Saturday, August .For more information about this year’s Summer Reading Challenge please visit www.liveleaberdeenshire.org.uk libraries.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fraserburghherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Rebel spent  days at the Scottish SPCA centre"  Rebel finds forever home viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "FRAS | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "FRAS | Article Teaser"

title: vandals strike at golf course
story: One of the clubs green keepers found the tyre marks on the th green yesterday morning.Damage at the th greenGreens Convenor of Oldmeldrum Golf Club, Mitch Good, believes the signicant damage was created by vandals using a small car.He said: "A message was put on our staff group chat about the damage at around half past six on Sunday morning."Since discovering it our green keeper Janice has been seeding and sanding the damaged areas and unfortunately that section of the green is now out of action."When it will open again depends on the weather as we need sun, rain and some heat to get the grass to grow."Mitch added: "We have a very friendly course here and our members will be devastated and very upset by this, they pay a lot of money to come and play here."It is a shame that this has happened as the green was looking fantastic over the last couple of weeks."Our green keepers have been working hard to get the green in great condition."Police Scotland have been made aware of the damage and anyone with any information should contact  or Crimestoppers on   to remain anonymous.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: campaign to offer free child car seat safety checks
story: When it comes to getting a handle on the details of child car seat safety, it’s the little things that matter.That’s the message coming from Orkney’s Road Safety Forum ahead of free car seat checks being offered in Orkney next month when the national ‘Good Egg’ campaign visits the county. per cent of car seats checked at last year’s #Good Egg# clinic in Orkney were found to be incorrectly fitted.The good news is that most of these —  per cent — were minor and easily rectiable issues such as incorrect harness or head-rest height, too much slack in belts or harnesses, or having the carry handle in the wrong position.But it’s these little details can make a big dference to children’s safety says Councillor Andrew Drever, chairman of the Orkney Road Safety Forum: “Any emergency service representative will tell you that making sure your car seat is fitted properly to your child and your vehicle can make all the dference when it comes to decreasing the risk of serious injury in the event of an accident.”The Road Safety Forum — which includes partners such as Orkney Islands Council, NHS Orkney, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue, and Scottish Ambulance Service — has helped arrange and publicise the Good Egg clinics since they started visiting Orkney in . This year local Scottish Fire and Rescue team will once again have a fire engine at the clinic to help draw attention to the clinic.Councillor Drever added: #The safety checks are carried out by a specially trained Good Egg Safety expert, not police officers # so people should not feel they are at risk of getting into trouble.“Rather it#s an opportunity to get some reassurance that your car seat is compatible with your vehicle, and to get tips and advice on any adjustments that would improve the car seat’s performance. We#d urge anyone who drives children about # whether that#s childminders, grandparents and parents or wider friends – to drop into the clinic. It is five or ten minutes of your time well spent.”The Good Egg Safety Child Seat clinic will be held in the Tesco car park in Kirkwall on Wednesday July , running from am to pm. There#s no need to book — just look for the Good Egg rep in the Tesco foyer, or head for the red fire engine.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
